title: Ukraine
text:
Ukraine (, ) is a country in <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>. It is the <a href="List%20of%20European%20countries%20by%20area">second-largest country by area</a> in Europe after <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, which it borders to the east and north-east. Ukraine also shares borders with <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a> to the north; <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="Slovakia">Slovakia</a>, and <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a> to the west; <a href="Romania">Romania</a> and <a href="Moldova">Moldova</a> to the south; and has a coastline along the <a href="Sea%20of%20Azov">Sea of Azov</a> and the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>. It spans an area of , with a population of 41.3 million, and is the <a href="List%20of%20European%20countries%20by%20population">eighth-most populous country</a> in Europe. The nation's capital and <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20Ukraine">largest city</a> is <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>.
The territory of modern Ukraine has been inhabited since 32,000 BC. During the <a href="Middle%20Ages">Middle Ages</a>, the area was a key centre of <a href="East%20Slavs">East Slavic</a> culture, with the powerful state of <a href="Kievan%20Rus%27">Kievan Rus'</a> forming the basis of Ukrainian identity. Following its fragmentation into several principalities in the 13th century and the devastation created by the <a href="Mongol%20invasion%20of%20Kievan%20Rus%27">Mongol invasion</a>, the territorial unity collapsed and the area was contested, divided, and ruled by a variety of powers, including the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>, <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and <a href="Tsardom%20of%20Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>. A <a href="Cossack%20Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a> emerged and prospered during the 17th and 18th centuries, but its territory was eventually split between <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Poland</a> and the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>. In the aftermath of the <a href="Russian%20Revolution">Russian Revolution</a>, a Ukrainian national movement for self-determination emerged, and the internationally recognized <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> was declared on 23 June 1917. After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the western part of Ukraine merged into the <a href="Ukrainian%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>, and the whole country became a part of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>. Ukraine gained its independence in 1991, following the <a href="dissolution%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>.
Following its independence, Ukraine declared itself a <a href="neutral%20state">neutral state</a>; it formed a limited military partnership with Russia and other <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Independent%20States">CIS countries</a> while also establishing a <a href="Partnership%20for%20Peace">partnership with NATO</a> in 1994. In 2013, after the government of President <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> had decided to suspend the <a href="Ukraine%E2%80%93European%20Union%20Association%20Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a> and seek closer economic ties with Russia, a several-months-long wave of demonstrations and protests known as the <a href="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> began, which later escalated into the <a href="Revolution%20of%20Dignity">Revolution of Dignity</a> that led to the overthrow of Yanukovych and the establishment of a new government. These events formed the background for the <a href="annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation">annexation of Crimea by Russia</a> in March 2014 and the <a href="War%20in%20Donbas">War in Donbas</a> in April 2014. On 1 January 2016, Ukraine applied for the economic component of the <a href="Deep%20and%20Comprehensive%20Free%20Trade%20Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> with the European Union.
Ukraine is a <a href="developing%20country">developing country</a> ranking 74th in the <a href="Human%20Development%20Index">Human Development Index</a>. It is the <a href="List%20of%20sovereign%20states%20in%20Europe%20by%20GDP%20%28nominal%29%20per%20capita">poorest country in Europe</a>, suffering from a very high poverty rate as well as severe <a href="Corruption%20in%20Ukraine">corruption</a>. However, because of its extensive fertile farmlands, Ukraine is one of the largest <a href="Grain%20trade">grain exporters</a> in the world. It also maintains the <a href="Military%20of%20Ukraine">third-largest military</a> in Europe after <a href="Russian%20Armed%20Forces">Russia</a> and <a href="French%20Armed%20Forces">France</a>. Ukraine is a <a href="unitary%20state">unitary republic</a> under a <a href="semi-presidential%20system">semi-presidential system</a> with <a href="separation%20of%20powers">separation of powers</a> into <a href="Legislative%20branch">legislative</a>, <a href="Executive%20branch">executive</a>, and <a href="Judicial%20branch">judicial</a> branches. The country is a member of the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a>, the <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a>, the <a href="Organization%20for%20Security%20and%20Co-operation%20in%20Europe">OSCE</a>, the <a href="GUAM%20Organization%20for%20Democracy%20and%20Economic%20Development">GUAM organization</a>, and the <a href="Lublin%20Triangle">Lublin Triangle</a>, and is one of the founding states of the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Independent%20States">CIS</a>, even though it never became a member of the organization.
Etymology and orthography.
There are different hypotheses as to the etymological origins of the <a href="name%20of%20Ukraine">name of Ukraine</a>. The most widespread hypothesis theorizes that it comes from the old Slavic term for "borderland".
"The Ukraine" used to be a frequently used form in English throughout the 20th century, but since the <a href="Declaration%20of%20Independence%20of%20Ukraine">Declaration of Independence of Ukraine</a> in 1991, "the Ukraine" has become less common in the <a href="English-speaking%20world">English-speaking world</a>, and style-guides warn against its use in professional writing. According to U.S. ambassador <a href="William%20B.%20Taylor%2C%20Jr.">William Taylor</a>, "the Ukraine" now implies disregard for the country's sovereignty. The official Ukrainian position is that the usage of "'the Ukraine' is incorrect both grammatically and politically."
History.
Early history.
<a href="Neanderthal">Neanderthal</a> settlement in Ukraine is seen in the Molodova archaeological sites (43,000–45,000 BC) which include a mammoth bone dwelling. The territory is also considered to be the likely location for the human <a href="domestication%20of%20the%20horse">domestication of the horse</a>.
Modern human settlement in Ukraine and its vicinity dates back to 32,000 BC, with evidence of the <a href="Gravettian%20culture">Gravettian culture</a> in the <a href="Crimean%20Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a>. By 4,500 BC, the <a href="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> <a href="Cucuteni%E2%80%93Trypillia%20culture">Cucuteni–Trypillia culture</a> flourished in wide areas of modern Ukraine including <a href="Trypillia">Trypillia</a> and the entire <a href="Dnieper">Dnieper</a>-<a href="Dniester">Dniester</a> region. During the <a href="Iron%20Age">Iron Age</a>, the land was inhabited by <a href="Cimmerians">Cimmerians</a>, <a href="Scythians">Scythians</a>, and <a href="Sarmatians">Sarmatians</a>. Between 700 BC and 200 BC it was part of the Scythian Kingdom, or <a href="Scythia">Scythia</a>.
Beginning in the sixth century BC, colonies of <a href="Ancient%20Greece">Ancient Greece</a>, <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Ancient Rome</a>, and the <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>, such as <a href="Tyras">Tyras</a>, <a href="Olbia%2C%20Ukraine">Olbia</a>, and <a href="Chersonesus">Chersonesus</a>, were founded on the northeastern shore of the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>. These colonies thrived well into the sixth century AD. The <a href="Goths">Goths</a> stayed in the area, but came under the sway of the <a href="Huns">Huns</a> from the 370s AD. In the seventh century AD, the territory that is now eastern Ukraine was the centre of <a href="Old%20Great%20Bulgaria">Old Great Bulgaria</a>. At the end of the century, the majority of Bulgar tribes migrated in different directions, and the <a href="Khazars">Khazars</a> took over much of the land.
In the fifth and sixth centuries, the <a href="Antes%20%28people%29">Antes</a> were located in the territory of what is now Ukraine. The Antes were the ancestors of <a href="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a>: <a href="White%20Croats">White Croats</a>, <a href="Severians">Severians</a>, <a href="Polans%20%28eastern%29">Polans</a>, <a href="Drevlyans">Drevlyans</a>, <a href="Dulebes">Dulebes</a>, <a href="Ulichians">Ulichians</a>, and <a href="Tiverians">Tiverians</a>. Migrations from Ukraine throughout the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a> established many <a href="South%20Slavs">South Slavic</a> nations. Northern migrations, reaching almost to the <a href="Lake%20Ilmen">Ilmen</a> lakes, led to the emergence of the <a href="Ilmen%20Slavs">Ilmen Slavs</a>, <a href="Krivichs">Krivichs</a>, and <a href="Radimichs">Radimichs</a>, the groups ancestral to the <a href="Russians">Russians</a>. After an Avar raid in 602 and the collapse of the Antes Union, most of these peoples survived as separate tribes until the beginning of the second millennium.
Golden Age of Kyiv.
Kievan Rus' was founded in the territory of the <a href="Polans%20%28eastern%29">Eastern Polans</a>, who lived among the rivers <a href="Ros%20River">Ros</a>, <a href="Rosava%20River">Rosava</a>, and <a href="Dnieper">Dnieper</a>. Russian historian <a href="Boris%20Rybakov">Boris Rybakov</a> came from studying the linguistics of Russian chronicles to the conclusion that the Polans union of clans of the mid-Dnieper region called itself by the name of one of its clans, "Ros", that joined the union and was known at least since the 6th century far beyond the Slavic world.
The origin of the Kyiv princedom is of a big debate and there exist at least three versions depending on interpretations of the chronicles. In general it is believed that Kievan Rus' included the central, western and northern part of modern Ukraine, <a href="Belarus">Belarus</a>, the far eastern strip of Poland and the western part of present-day Russia. According to the "<a href="Primary%20Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a>" the Rus' elite initially consisted of <a href="Varangian">Varangian</a>s from <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>.
During the 10th and 11th centuries, it became the largest and most powerful state in Europe. It laid the foundation for the national identity of Ukrainians and Russians. <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, the capital of modern Ukraine, became the most important city of the Rus'. In 12th–13th centuries on efforts of <a href="Yuri%20the%20Long%20Armed">Yuri the Long Armed</a>, in area of <a href="Zalesye">Zalesye</a> were founded several cities similar in name as in Kievan Rus' such as <a href="Vladimir%2C%20Russia">Vladimir on the Klyazma</a>/Vladimir of Zalesye (<a href="Volodymyr-Volynsky">Volodymyr</a>), <a href="Galich%2C%20Russia">Galich of Merya</a> (<a href="Halych">Halych</a>), <a href="Pereslavl-Zalessky">Pereslavl of Zalesye</a> (<a href="Pereyaslav-Khmelnytskyi">Pereyaslav of Ruthenian</a>), <a href="Ryazan">Pereslavl of Erzya</a>.
The Varangians later assimilated into the Slavic population and became part of the first Rus' dynasty, the <a href="Rurik%20dynasty">Rurik dynasty</a>. Kievan Rus' was composed of several <a href="principality">principalities</a> ruled by the interrelated Rurikid "<a href="knyaz">kniazes</a>" ("princes"), who often fought each other for possession of Kyiv.
The Golden Age of Kievan Rus' began with the reign of <a href="Vladimir%20the%20Great">Vladimir the Great</a> (980–1015), who <a href="Christianization%20of%20Kievan%20Rus%27">turned Rus' toward Byzantine Christianity</a>. During the reign of his son, <a href="Yaroslav%20the%20Wise">Yaroslav the Wise</a> (1019–1054), Kievan Rus' reached the zenith of its cultural development and military power. The state soon fragmented as the relative importance of regional powers rose again. After a final resurgence under the rule of <a href="Vladimir%20II%20Monomakh">Vladimir II Monomakh</a> (1113–1125) and his son <a href="Mstislav%20I%20of%20Kiev">Mstislav</a> (1125–1132), Kievan Rus' finally disintegrated into separate principalities following Mstislav's death.
The 13th-century <a href="Mongol%20invasion%20of%20Rus%27">Mongol invasion</a> devastated Kievan Rus'. Kyiv was totally <a href="Siege%20of%20Kyiv%20%281240%29">destroyed in 1240</a>. On today's Ukrainian territory, the principalities of <a href="Principality%20of%20Halych">Halych</a> and <a href="Volhynia">Volodymyr-Volynskyi</a> arose, and were merged into the state of <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia">Galicia–Volhynia</a>.
<a href="Daniel%20of%20Galicia">Danylo Romanovych</a> (Daniel I of Galicia or Danylo Halytskyi) son of <a href="Roman%20the%20Great">Roman Mstyslavych</a>, re-united all of south-western Rus', including Volhynia, Galicia and Rus' ancient capital of Kyiv. Danylo was crowned by the <a href="Pope">papal</a> <a href="archbishop">archbishop</a> in <a href="Drohiczyn">Dorohychyn</a> 1253 as the first <a href="Monarch">king</a> of all Rus'. Under Danylo's reign, the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia">Kingdom of Ruthenia</a> was one of the most powerful states in east central Europe.
Foreign domination.
In the mid-14th century, upon the death of <a href="Boles%C5%82aw%20Jerzy%20II%20of%20Mazovia">Bolesław Jerzy II of Mazovia</a>, king <a href="Casimir%20III%20of%20Poland">Casimir III of Poland</a> initiated campaigns (1340–1366) to take Galicia-Volhynia. Meanwhile, the heartland of Rus', including Kyiv, became the territory of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania, ruled by <a href="Gediminas">Gediminas</a> and his successors, after the <a href="Battle%20on%20the%20Irpen%27%20River">Battle on the Irpen' River</a>. Following the 1386 <a href="Union%20of%20Krewo">Union of Krewo</a>, a <a href="dynastic%20union">dynastic union</a> between Poland and Lithuania, much of what became northern Ukraine was ruled by the increasingly Slavicised local Lithuanian nobles as part of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania. By 1392 the so-called <a href="Galicia%E2%80%93Volhynia%20Wars">Galicia–Volhynia Wars</a> ended. Polish colonisers of depopulated lands in northern and central Ukraine founded or re-founded many towns.
In the Black Sea cities of modern-day Ukraine, the <a href="Republic%20of%20Genoa">Republic of Genoa</a> founded numerous colonies, from the mid-13th century to the late 15th century, including the cities of <a href="Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi">Bilhorod-Dnistrovskyi</a> ("Moncastro") and <a href="Kiliya">Kiliya</a> ("Licostomo"), the colonies used to be large commercial centers in the region, and were headed by a consul (a representative of the Republic).
In 1430 <a href="Podolia">Podolia</a> was incorporated under the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland as <a href="Podolian%20Voivodeship">Podolian Voivodeship</a>. In 1441, in the southern Ukraine, especially Crimea and surrounding steppes, <a href="Genghisid">Genghisid</a> prince <a href="Haci%20I%20Giray">Haci I Giray</a> founded the Crimean Khanate.
In 1569 the <a href="Union%20of%20Lublin">Union of Lublin</a> established the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth, and much Ukrainian territory was transferred from Lithuania to the Crown of the Kingdom of Poland, becoming Polish territory de jure. Under the demographic, cultural and political pressure of <a href="Polonisation">Polonisation</a>, which began in the late 14th century, many landed gentry of Polish <a href="Ruthenia">Ruthenia</a> (another name for the land of Rus) converted to Catholicism and became indistinguishable from the <a href="Polish%20nobility">Polish nobility</a>. Deprived of native protectors among Rus nobility, the commoners (peasants and townspeople) began turning for protection to the emerging <a href="Zaporozhian%20Cossacks">Zaporozhian Cossacks</a>, who by the 17th century became devoutly <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Orthodox</a>. The Cossacks did not shy from taking up arms against those they perceived as enemies, including the Polish state and its local representatives.
Formed from <a href="Golden%20Horde">Golden Horde</a> territory conquered after the <a href="Mongol%20invasion%23European%20vassals">Mongol invasion</a> the <a href="Crimean%20Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a> was one of the strongest powers in Eastern Europe until the 18th century; in 1571 it even <a href="Russo-Crimean%20Wars">captured and devastated Moscow</a>. The borderlands suffered annual <a href="Crimean-Nogai%20raids%20into%20East%20Slavic%20lands">Tatar invasions</a>. From the beginning of the 16th century until the end of the 17th century, Crimean Tatar <a href="slave%20raiding">slave raiding</a> bands exported about two million slaves from Russia and Ukraine.
According to <a href="Orest%20Subtelny">Orest Subtelny</a>, "from 1450 to 1586, eighty-six <a href="Tatar%20invasions">Tatar raids</a> were recorded, and from 1600 to 1647, seventy." In 1688, Tatars captured a record number of 60,000 Ukrainians. The Tatar raids took a heavy toll, discouraging settlement in more southerly regions where the soil was better and the growing season was longer. The last remnant of the Crimean Khanate was finally conquered by the Russian Empire in 1783.
In the mid-17th century, a Cossack military quasi-state, the <a href="Zaporozhian%20Host">Zaporozhian Host</a>, was formed by <a href="Dnieper%20Cossacks">Dnieper Cossacks</a> and by Ruthenian peasants who had fled Polish <a href="serfdom">serfdom</a>. Poland exercised little real control over this population, but found the Cossacks to be a useful opposing force to the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Turks</a> and <a href="Crimean%20Khanate">Tatars</a>, and at times the two were allies in <a href="Ottoman%20wars%20in%20Europe">military campaigns</a>. However, the continued harsh <a href="serf">enserfment</a> of peasantry by Polish nobility and especially the suppression of the Orthodox Church alienated the Cossacks.
The Cossacks sought representation in the Polish <a href="Sejm%20generalny">Sejm</a>, recognition of Orthodox traditions, and the gradual expansion of the <a href="Registered%20Cossacks">Cossack Registry</a>. These were rejected by the Polish nobility, who dominated the Sejm.
Cossack Hetmanate.
In 1648, <a href="Bohdan%20Khmelnytsky">Bohdan Khmelnytsky</a> and <a href="Petro%20Doroshenko">Petro Doroshenko</a> led the <a href="Khmelnytsky%20Uprising">largest of the Cossack uprisings</a> against the Commonwealth and the Polish king. After Khmelnytsky made an entry into Kyiv in 1648, where he was hailed liberator of the people from Polish captivity, he founded the <a href="Cossack%20Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a>, which existed until 1764 (some sources claim until 1782). 
Khmelnytsky, deserted by his Tatar allies, suffered a crushing defeat at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Berestechko">Battle of Berestechko</a> in 1651, and turned to the Russian tsar for help. In 1654, Khmelnytsky was subject to the <a href="Pereyaslav%20Council">Pereyaslav Council</a>, forming a military and political alliance with Russia that acknowledged loyalty to the Russian tsar.
In the period 1657–1686 came "<a href="The%20Ruin%20%28Ukrainian%20history%29">The Ruin</a>", a devastating 30-year war amongst Russia, Poland, the <a href="Crimean%20Khanate">Crimean Khanate</a>, the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>, and <a href="Cossacks">Cossacks</a> for control of Ukraine, which occurred at about the same time as the <a href="Deluge%20%28history%29">Deluge</a> of Poland. The wars escalated in intensity with hundreds of thousands of deaths. The "<a href="Treaty%20of%20Perpetual%20Peace%20%281686%29">Treaty of Perpetual Peace</a>" between Russia and Poland in 1686 divided the lands of the Cossack Hetmanate between them, reducing the portion over which Poland had claimed sovereignty.
In 1686, the <a href="Metropolitanate%20of%20Kyiv">Metropolitanate of Kyiv</a> was <a href="Annexation%20of%20the%20Metropolitanate%20of%20Kyiv%20by%20the%20Moscow%20Patriarchate">annexed by the Moscow Patriarchate</a> through the Synodal Letter of the <a href="Ecumenical%20Patriarch%20of%20Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople</a> <a href="Dionysius%20IV%20of%20Constantinople">Dionysius IV</a> (later <a href="anathema">anathema</a>tized), who made a <a href="simony">simony</a>.
In 1709, Cossack Hetman <a href="Ivan%20Mazepa">Ivan Mazepa</a> (1639–1709) defected to <a href="Sweden">Sweden</a> against Russia in the <a href="Great%20Northern%20War">Great Northern War</a> (1700–1721). Eventually Tsar <a href="Peter%20the%20Great">Peter</a> recognized that to consolidate and modernize Russia's political and economic power it was necessary to do away with the Cossack Hetmanate and Ukrainian and Cossack aspirations to autonomy. Mazepa died in exile after fleeing from the <a href="Battle%20of%20Poltava">Battle of Poltava</a> (1709), in which the Swedes and their Cossack allies suffered a catastrophic defeat.
The <a href="Constitution%20of%20Pylyp%20Orlyk">Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk</a> or Pacts and Constitutions of Rights and Freedoms of the Zaporizhian Host was a 1710 constitutional document written by <a href="Hetman">Hetman</a> <a href="Pylyp%20Orlyk">Pylyp Orlyk</a>, a Cossack of Ukraine, then within the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>. It established a standard for the <a href="separation%20of%20powers">separation of powers</a> in government between the legislative, executive, and judiciary branches, well before the publication of <a href="Montesquieu">Montesquieu</a>'s "<a href="The%20Spirit%20of%20the%20Laws">The Spirit of the Laws</a>". The Constitution limited the executive authority of the hetman, and established a democratically elected Cossack parliament called the General Council. The <a href="Constitution%20of%20Pylyp%20Orlyk">Constitution of Pylyp Orlyk</a> was unique for its period, and was one of the first state constitutions in Europe.
The hetmanate was abolished in 1764; the <a href="Zaporozhian%20Sich">Zaporozhian Sich</a> was abolished in 1775, as Russia centralised control over its lands. As part of the <a href="Partitions%20of%20Poland">Partitions of Poland</a> in 1772, 1793 and 1795, the Ukrainian lands west of the Dnieper were divided between Russia and Austria. From 1737 to 1834, expansion into the northern Black Sea littoral and the eastern <a href="Danube">Danube</a> valley was a cornerstone of Russian foreign policy.
Lithuanians and Poles controlled vast estates in Ukraine, and were a law unto themselves. Judicial rulings from <a href="Krak%C3%B3w">Kraków</a> were routinely flouted, while peasants were heavily taxed and practically tied to the land as <a href="serfdom">serfs</a>. Occasionally the landowners battled each other using armies of Ukrainian peasants. The Poles and Lithuanians were Roman Catholics and tried with some success to convert the Orthodox lesser nobility. In 1596, they set up the "Greek-Catholic" or <a href="Ukrainian%20Greek%20Catholic%20Church">Uniate Church</a>; it dominates western Ukraine to this day. Religious differentiation left the Ukrainian Orthodox peasants leaderless, as they were reluctant to follow the Ukrainian nobles.
Cossacks led an uprising, called <a href="Koliivshchyna">Koliivshchyna</a>, starting in the Ukrainian borderlands of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth in 1768. Ethnicity was one root cause of this revolt, which included the <a href="Massacre%20of%20Uman">Massacre of Uman</a> that killed tens of thousands of Poles and Jews. Religious warfare also broke out among Ukrainian groups. Increasing conflict between Uniate and Orthodox parishes along the newly reinforced Polish-Russian border on the <a href="Dnieper">Dnieper</a> in the time of <a href="Catherine%20the%20Great">Catherine the Great</a> set the stage for the uprising. As Uniate religious practices had become more Latinized, Orthodoxy in this region drew even closer into dependence on the <a href="Russian%20Orthodox%20Church">Russian Orthodox Church</a>. Confessional tensions also reflected opposing Polish and Russian political allegiances.
After the <a href="annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Empire">annexation of Crimea by the Russian Empire</a> in 1783, <a href="Novorossiya">Novorossiya</a> was settled by Ukrainians and Russians. Despite promises in the Treaty of Pereyaslav, the Ukrainian elite and the Cossacks never received the freedoms and the autonomy they had expected. However, within the Empire, Ukrainians rose to the highest Russian state and church offices. In a later period, <a href="tsarist%20autocracy">tsarists</a> established a policy of <a href="Russification">Russification</a>, suppressing the use of the Ukrainian language in print and in public.
19th century, World War I and revolution.
In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the territory of today's Ukraine was included in the <a href="Governorate%20%28Russia%29">governorates</a> of <a href="Chernigov%20Governorate">Chernihiv (Chernigov in Russian)</a>, <a href="Kharkov%20Governorate">Kharkiv (Kharkov)</a>, <a href="Kiev%20Governorate%20%281708%E2%80%931764%29">Kyiv 1708–1764</a>, and <a href="Little%20Russia%20Governorate%20%281764%E2%80%931781%29">Little Russia 1764–1781</a>, <a href="Podolian%20Governorate">Podillia (Podolie)</a>, and <a href="Volhynian%20Governorate">Volyn</a> (Volhynia)—with all but the first two informally grouped into the <a href="Southwestern%20Krai">Southwestern Krai</a>.
After the <a href="Russo-Turkish%20War%20%281768%E2%80%931774%29">Russo-Turkish War (1768–1774)</a>, <a href="Catherine%20the%20Great">Catherine the Great</a> and her immediate successors encouraged German immigration into Ukraine and especially <a href="Crimea%20Germans">into Crimea</a>, to thin the previously dominant Turk population and encourage agriculture. Numerous Ukrainians, Russians, Germans, <a href="Bulgarians%20in%20Ukraine">Bulgarians</a>, <a href="Serbs%20in%20Ukraine">Serbs</a> and <a href="Greeks%20in%20Ukraine">Greeks</a> moved into the northern <a href="Pontic%E2%80%93Caspian%20steppe">Black Sea steppe</a> formerly known as the "<a href="Wild%20Fields">Wild Fields</a>".
With growing urbanization and modernization, and a cultural trend toward <a href="romantic%20nationalism">romantic nationalism</a>, a Ukrainian <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a> committed to national rebirth and social justice emerged. The serf-turned-national-poet <a href="Taras%20Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a> (1814–1861) and the political theorist <a href="Mykhailo%20Drahomanov">Mykhailo Drahomanov</a> (1841–1895) led the growing nationalist movement.
Beginning in the 19th century, there was migration from Ukraine to distant areas of the Russian Empire. According to the 1897 census, there were 223,000 ethnic Ukrainians in <a href="Siberia">Siberia</a> and 102,000 in <a href="Central%20Asia">Central Asia</a>. An additional 1.6 million emigrated to the east in the ten years after the opening of the <a href="Trans-Siberian%20Railway">Trans-Siberian Railway</a> in 1906. <a href="Russian%20Far%20East">Far Eastern</a> areas with an ethnic Ukrainian population became known as <a href="Green%20Ukraine">Green Ukraine</a>.
Nationalist and socialist parties developed in the late 19th century. Austrian <a href="Galicia%20%28eastern%20Europe%29">Galicia</a>, under the relatively lenient rule of the <a href="Habsburgs">Habsburgs</a>, became the centre of the nationalist movement.
Ukrainians entered <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a> on the side of both the <a href="Central%20Powers">Central Powers</a>, under Austria, and the <a href="Triple%20Entente">Triple Entente</a>, under Russia. Three-and-a-half million Ukrainians fought with the <a href="Military%20history%20of%20Imperial%20Russia">Imperial Russian Army</a>, while 250,000 fought for the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Army">Austro-Hungarian Army</a>. <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> authorities established the Ukrainian Legion to fight against the Russian Empire. This became the <a href="Ukrainian%20Galician%20Army">Ukrainian Galician Army</a> that fought against the Bolsheviks and Poles in the post-World War I period (1919–23). Those suspected of Russophile sentiments in Austria were treated harshly.
World War I destroyed both empires. The <a href="Russian%20Revolution">Russian Revolution of 1917</a> led to the founding of the Soviet Union under the <a href="Bolsheviks">Bolsheviks</a>, and subsequent <a href="Russian%20Civil%20War">civil war in Russia</a>. A Ukrainian national movement for self-determination emerged, with heavy Communist and Socialist influence. Several Ukrainian states briefly emerged: the internationally recognized <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> ("UPR", the predecessor of modern Ukraine, was declared on 23 June 1917 by the <a href="First%20Universal%20of%20the%20Ukrainian%20Central%20Council">First Universal</a> proclaimed at first as a part of the <a href="Russian%20Republic">Russian Republic</a>; after the <a href="October%20Revolution">October Revolution</a>, the Ukrainian People's Republic proclaimed its independence on 22 January 1918 by the <a href="Fourth%20Universal%20of%20the%20Ukrainian%20Central%20Council">Fourth Universal</a>), the <a href="Ukrainian%20State">Hetmanate</a>, the <a href="Directorate%20of%20Ukraine">Directorate</a> and the Bolshevik <a href="Ukrainian%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic</a> (or Soviet Ukraine) successively established territories in the former Russian Empire; while the <a href="West%20Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">West Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="Hutsul%20Republic">Hutsul Republic</a> emerged briefly in the Ukrainian lands of former Austro-Hungarian territory.
The short-lived <a href="Unification%20Act">Unification Act</a> was an agreement signed on 22 January 1919 by the <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="West%20Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">West Ukrainian People's Republic</a> on the <a href="Saint%20Sophia%20Cathedral%20in%20Kyiv">St. Sophia Square</a> in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>. This led to civil war, and an <a href="Anarchism">anarchist</a> movement called the <a href="Black%20Guards">Black Army</a> (later renamed to the <a href="Revolutionary%20Insurrectionary%20Army%20of%20Ukraine">Revolutionary Insurrectionary Army of Ukraine</a>) developed in Southern Ukraine under the command of the anarchist <a href="Nestor%20Makhno">Nestor Makhno</a> during the <a href="Russian%20Civil%20War">Russian Civil War</a>. They protected the operation of "<a href="Soviet%20%28council%29">free soviets</a>" and <a href="libertarian%20socialism">libertarian</a> <a href="communes">communes</a> in the <a href="Free%20Territory">Free Territory</a>, an attempt to form a <a href="Stateless%20society">stateless</a> <a href="Anarchism">anarchist</a> society from 1918 to 1921 during the <a href="Ukrainian%20War%20of%20Independence">Ukrainian Revolution</a>, fighting both the tsarist <a href="Armed%20Forces%20of%20South%20Russia">White Army</a> under <a href="Anton%20Denikin">Denikin</a> and later the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> under <a href="Leon%20Trotsky">Trotsky</a>, before being defeated by the latter in August 1921.
Poland defeated Western Ukraine in the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Ukrainian%20War">Polish–Ukrainian War</a>, but failed against the Bolsheviks in <a href="Kyiv%20Offensive%20%281920%29">an offensive against Kyiv</a>. According to the <a href="Peace%20of%20Riga">Peace of Riga</a>, western Ukraine was incorporated into Poland, which in turn recognised the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic in March 1919. With establishment of the Soviet power, Ukraine lost half of its territory, while Moldavian autonomy was established on the left bank of the <a href="Dniester">Dniester</a> River. Ukraine became a founding member of the <a href="Union%20of%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republics">Union of Soviet Socialist Republics</a> in December 1922.
Western Ukraine, Carpathian Ruthenia and Bukovina.
The war in Ukraine continued for another two years; by 1921, however, most of Ukraine had been taken over by the Soviet Union, while Galicia and Volhynia (mostly today's <a href="West%20Ukraine">West Ukraine</a>) were incorporated into the <a href="Second%20Polish%20Republic">Second Polish Republic</a>. Modern-day <a href="Bukovina">Bukovina</a> was annexed by Romania and <a href="Carpathian%20Ruthenia">Carpathian Ruthenia</a> was admitted to the <a href="First%20Czechoslovak%20Republic">Czechoslovak Republic</a> as an autonomy.
A powerful underground Ukrainian nationalist movement arose in eastern Poland in the 1920s and 1930s, which was formed by Ukrainian veterans of the <a href="Ukrainian-Soviet%20war">Ukrainian-Soviet war</a> (including <a href="Yevhen%20Konovalets">Yevhen Konovalets</a>, <a href="Andriy%20Atanasovych%20Melnyk">Andriy Melnyk</a>, and <a href="Yuriy%20Tyutyunyk">Yuriy Tyutyunyk</a>) and was transformed into the <a href="Ukrainian%20Military%20Organization">Ukrainian Military Organization</a> and later the <a href="Organisation%20of%20Ukrainian%20Nationalists">Organisation of Ukrainian Nationalists</a> (OUN). The movement attracted a militant following among students. Hostilities between Polish state authorities and the popular movement led to a substantial number of fatalities, and the autonomy which had been promised was never implemented.
The pre-war Polish government also exercised <a href="anti-Ukrainian%20sentiment">anti-Ukrainian sentiment</a>; it restricted rights of people who declared Ukrainian nationality, belonged to the <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Eastern Orthodox Church</a> and inhabited the <a href="Eastern%20Borderlands">Eastern Borderlands</a>. The <a href="Ukrainian%20language">Ukrainian language</a> was restricted in every field possible, especially in governmental institutions, and the term "Ruthenian" was enforced in an attempt to ban the use of the term "Ukrainian". Despite this, a number of Ukrainian parties, the Ukrainian Catholic Church, an active press, and a business sector existed in Poland. Economic conditions improved in the 1920s, but the region suffered from the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a> in the early 1930s.
Inter-war Soviet Ukraine.
The <a href="Russian%20Civil%20War">Russian Civil War</a> devastated the whole <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a> including Ukraine. It left over 1.5 million people dead and hundreds of thousands homeless in the former Russian Empire territory. Soviet Ukraine also faced the <a href="Russian%20famine%20of%201921">Russian famine of 1921</a> (primarily affecting the Russian <a href="Volga%20Region">Volga</a>-<a href="Ural%20%28region%29">Ural</a> region). During the 1920s, under the Ukrainisation policy pursued by the national Communist leadership of <a href="Mykola%20Skrypnyk">Mykola Skrypnyk</a>, Soviet leadership encouraged a national renaissance in the <a href="Culture%20of%20Ukraine">Ukrainian culture</a> and <a href="Ukrainian%20language">language</a>. <a href="Ukrainisation">Ukrainisation</a> was part of the Soviet-wide policy of <a href="Korenisation">Korenisation</a> (literally "indigenisation").
The Bolsheviks were also committed to <a href="universal%20health%20care">universal health care</a>, education and social-security benefits, as well as the right to work and housing. <a href="Women%27s%20rights">Women's rights</a> were greatly increased through new laws. Most of these policies were sharply reversed by the early 1930s after <a href="Joseph%20Stalin">Joseph Stalin</a> became the "de facto" communist party leader.
Starting from the late 1920s with a <a href="first%20five-year%20plan">centrally planned economy</a>, Ukraine was involved in <a href="Industrialization%20in%20the%20USSR">Soviet industrialisation</a> and the republic's industrial output quadrupled during the 1930s. The peasantry suffered from the <a href="Collectivisation%20in%20the%20USSR">programme of collectivisation</a> of agriculture which began during and was part of the <a href="first%20five-year%20plan">first five-year plan</a> and was enforced by regular troops and <a href="Cheka">secret police</a>. Those who resisted were <a href="Population%20transfer%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">arrested and deported</a> and agricultural productivity greatly declined. As members of the collective farms were sometimes not allowed to receive any grain until unrealistic quotas were met, millions starved to death in a <a href="Droughts%20and%20famines%20in%20Russia%20and%20the%20Soviet%20Union">famine</a> known as the <a href="Holodomor">Holodomor</a> or the "Great Famine".
Scholars are divided as to whether this famine fits the definition of <a href="genocide">genocide</a>, but the <a href="Ukrainian%20parliament">Ukrainian parliament</a> and the governments of other countries have acknowledged it as such.
The Communist leadership perceived famine as a means of class struggle and used starvation as a punishment tool to force peasants into collective farms.
Largely the same groups were responsible for the mass killing operations during the civil war, collectivisation, and the <a href="Great%20Purge">Great Terror</a>. These groups were associated with <a href="Yefim%20Yevdokimov">Yefim Yevdokimov</a> (1891–1939) and operated in the Secret Operational Division within General State Political Administration (<a href="State%20Political%20Directorate">OGPU</a>) in 1929–31. Yevdokimov transferred into Communist Party administration in 1934, when he became Party secretary for <a href="North%20Caucasus%20Krai">North Caucasus Krai</a>. He appears to have continued advising Joseph Stalin and <a href="Nikolai%20Yezhov">Nikolai Yezhov</a> on security matters, and the latter relied on Yevdokimov's former colleagues to carry out the mass killing operations that are known as the Great Terror in 1937–38.
On 13 January 2010, Kyiv Appellate Court posthumously found Stalin, <a href="Lazar%20Kaganovich">Kaganovich</a> and other Soviet Communist Party functionaries guilty of <a href="genocide">genocide</a> against Ukrainians during the Holodomor famine.
World War II.
Following the <a href="Invasion%20of%20Poland">Invasion of Poland</a> in September 1939, <a href="Nazi%20Germany">German</a> and <a href="Soviet%20Army">Soviet</a> troops divided the territory of Poland. Thus, Eastern <a href="Galicia%20%28Eastern%20Europe%29">Galicia</a> and <a href="Volhynia">Volhynia</a> with their Ukrainian population became part of Ukraine. For the first time in history, the nation was united.
In 1940, the Soviets annexed <a href="Bessarabia">Bessarabia</a> and northern <a href="Bukovina">Bukovina</a>. The Ukrainian SSR incorporated the northern and southern districts of Bessarabia, Northern Bukovina, and the <a href="Hertsa%20region">Hertsa region</a>. But it ceded the western part of the <a href="Moldavian%20Autonomous%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic</a> to the newly created <a href="Moldavian%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Moldavian Soviet Socialist Republic</a>. These territorial gains of the USSR were internationally recognized by the <a href="Paris%20Peace%20Treaties%2C%201947">Paris peace treaties of 1947</a>.
<a href="Wehrmacht">German armies</a> <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">invaded the Soviet Union</a> on 22 June 1941, initiating nearly four years of <a href="total%20war">total war</a>. The <a href="Axis%20Powers">Axis</a> initially advanced against desperate but unsuccessful efforts of the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a>. In the encirclement <a href="Battle%20of%20Kyiv%20%281941%29">battle of Kyiv</a>, the city was acclaimed as a "<a href="Hero%20City">Hero City</a>", because of its fierce <a href="Battle%20of%20Kyiv%20%281941%29">resistance</a>. More than 600,000 Soviet soldiers (or one-quarter of the <a href="Soviet%20Western%20Front">Soviet Western Front</a>) were killed or taken captive there, with many suffering <a href="German%20mistreatment%20of%20Soviet%20prisoners%20of%20war">severe mistreatment</a>.
Although the majority of Ukrainians fought in or alongside the Red Army and <a href="Soviet%20partisans">Soviet resistance</a>, in Western Ukraine an independent <a href="Ukrainian%20Insurgent%20Army">Ukrainian Insurgent Army</a> movement arose (UPA, 1942). Created as armed forces of the underground (<a href="Organization%20of%20Ukrainian%20Nationalists">Organization of Ukrainian Nationalists</a>, OUN) which had developed in <a href="Second%20Polish%20Republic">interwar Poland</a> as a reactionary nationalist organization. During the interwar period, the <a href="History%20of%20the%20Ukrainian%20minority%20in%20Poland%23Policies%20of%20J%C3%B3zef%20Pi%C5%82sudski%20and%20the%20%26quot%3BVolhynia%20Experiment%26quot%3B">Polish government's policies towards the Ukrainian minority</a> were initially very accommodating; however, by the late 1930s they became increasingly harsh due to civil unrest.
Both organizations, the OUN and the UPA supported the goal of an <a href="Declaration%20of%20Ukrainian%20Independence%2C%201941">independent Ukrainian state</a> on the territory with a Ukrainian ethnic majority. Although this brought conflict with Nazi Germany, at times the <a href="Andriy%20Atanasovych%20Melnyk">Melnyk</a> wing of the OUN allied with the Nazi forces. Beginning in mid-1943 and lasting until the end of the war, UPA carried out <a href="Massacres%20of%20Poles%20in%20Volhynia%20and%20Eastern%20Galicia">massacres of ethnic Poles</a> in the <a href="Volhynia">Volhynia</a> and <a href="Eastern%20Galicia">Eastern Galicia</a> regions, killing around 100,000 Polish civilians, which brought reprisals.
The organized massacres were an attempt by OUN to create a homogeneous Ukrainian state without a Polish minority living within its borders, and to prevent the post-war Polish state from asserting its sovereignty over areas that had been part of prewar Poland. After the war, the UPA continued to fight the USSR until the 1950s. At the same time, the <a href="Ukrainian%20Liberation%20Army">Ukrainian Liberation Army</a>, another nationalist movement, fought alongside the Nazis.
In total, the number of ethnic Ukrainians who fought in the ranks of the Soviet Army is estimated from 4.5 million to 7 million. The <a href="Soviet%20Partisans">pro-Soviet partisan</a> guerrilla resistance in Ukraine is estimated to number at 47,800 from the start of occupation to 500,000 at its peak in 1944, with about 50% being ethnic Ukrainians. Generally, the Ukrainian Insurgent Army's figures are unreliable, with figures ranging anywhere from 15,000 to as many as 100,000 fighters.
Most of the Ukrainian SSR was organised within the <a href="Reichskommissariat%20Ukraine">Reichskommissariat Ukraine</a>, with the intention of exploiting its resources and eventual German settlement. Some western Ukrainians, who had only joined the Soviet Union in 1939, hailed the Germans as liberators. Brutal German rule eventually turned their supporters against the Nazi administrators, who made little attempt to exploit dissatisfaction with Stalinist policies. Instead, the Nazis preserved the collective-farm system, carried out <a href="Mass%20graves%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">genocidal policies</a> against <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Ukraine">Jews</a>, <a href="OST-Arbeiter">deported millions of people to work in Germany</a>, and began a depopulation program to prepare for German colonisation. They blockaded the transport of food on the Kyiv River.
The vast majority of the fighting in World War II took place on the <a href="Eastern%20Front%20%28World%20War%20II%29">Eastern Front</a>. By some estimates, 93% of all German casualties took place there. The <a href="World%20War%20II%20casualties%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">total losses</a> inflicted upon the Ukrainian population during the war are estimated at 6 million, including an estimated one and a half million Jews killed by the <a href="Einsatzgruppen">Einsatzgruppen</a>, sometimes with the help of local collaborators. Of the estimated 8.6 million Soviet troop losses, 1.4 million were ethnic <a href="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a>. <a href="Victory%20Day%20%28Eastern%20Front%29">Victory Day</a> is celebrated as one of ten Ukrainian national holidays. The losses of the Ukrainian people in the war amounted to 40-44% of the total losses of the USSR.
Post–World War II.
The republic was heavily damaged by the war, and it required significant efforts to recover. More than 700 cities and towns and 28,000 villages were destroyed. The situation was worsened by a <a href="famine">famine</a> in 1946–47, which was caused by a drought and the wartime destruction of infrastructure. The death toll of this famine varies, with even the lowest estimate in the tens of thousands. In 1945, the Ukrainian SSR became one of the founding members of the <a href="United%20Nations">United Nations</a> organization, part of a special agreement at the <a href="Yalta%20Conference">Yalta Conference</a>.
Post-war <a href="ethnic%20cleansing">ethnic cleansing</a> occurred in the newly expanded Soviet Union. As of 1 January 1953, Ukrainians were second only to Russians among adult "<a href="Forced%20settlements%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">special deportees</a>", comprising 20% of the total. In addition, over 450,000 ethnic <a href="History%20of%20Germans%20in%20Russia%2C%20Ukraine%20and%20the%20Soviet%20Union">Germans</a> from Ukraine and more than 200,000 <a href="Crimean%20Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> were victims of <a href="Population%20transfer%20in%20the%20Soviet%20Union">forced deportations</a>.
Following the death of <a href="Joseph%20Stalin">Stalin</a> in 1953, <a href="Nikita%20Khrushchev">Nikita Khrushchev</a> became the new leader of the USSR. Having served as First Secretary of the <a href="Communist%20Party%20%28Bolsheviks%29%20of%20Ukraine">Communist Party of Ukrainian SSR</a> in 1938–49, Khrushchev was intimately familiar with the republic; after taking power union-wide, he began to emphasize "the friendship" between the Ukrainian and Russian nations. In 1954, the 300th anniversary of the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Pereyaslav">Treaty of Pereyaslav</a> was widely celebrated. <a href="Crimean%20Oblast">Crimea</a> was <a href="1954%20transfer%20of%20Crimea">transferred</a> from the <a href="Russian%20SFSR">Russian SFSR</a> to the <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a>.
By 1950, the republic had fully surpassed pre-war levels of industry and production. During the 1946–1950 <a href="Five-Year%20Plan%20%28USSR%29">five-year plan</a>, nearly 20% of the Soviet budget was invested in Soviet Ukraine, a 5% increase from pre-war plans. As a result, the Ukrainian workforce rose 33.2% from 1940 to 1955 while industrial output grew 2.2 times in that same period.
Soviet Ukraine soon became a European leader in industrial production, and an important centre of the Soviet <a href="arms%20industry">arms industry</a> and high-tech research. Such an important role resulted in a major influence of the local elite. Many members of the Soviet leadership came from Ukraine, most notably <a href="Leonid%20Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a>. He later ousted Khrushchev and became the Soviet leader from 1964 to 1982. Many prominent Soviet sports players, scientists, and artists came from Ukraine.
On 26 April 1986, a reactor in the <a href="Chernobyl%20Nuclear%20Power%20Plant">Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant</a> exploded, resulting in the <a href="Chernobyl%20disaster">Chernobyl disaster</a>, the worst <a href="nuclear%20reactor">nuclear reactor</a> accident in history. This was the only accident to receive the highest possible rating of 7 by the <a href="International%20Nuclear%20Event%20Scale">International Nuclear Event Scale</a>, indicating a "major accident", until the <a href="Fukushima%20Daiichi%20nuclear%20disaster">Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster</a> in March 2011. At the time of the accident, 7 million people lived in the contaminated territories, including 2.2 million in Ukraine.
After the accident, the new city of <a href="Slavutych">Slavutych</a> was built outside the exclusion zone to house and support the employees of the plant, which was decommissioned in 2000. A report prepared by the <a href="International%20Atomic%20Energy%20Agency">International Atomic Energy Agency</a> and <a href="World%20Health%20Organization">World Health Organization</a> attributed 56 direct deaths to the accident and estimated that there may have been 4,000 extra cancer deaths.
Independence.
On 21 January 1990, over 300,000 Ukrainians organised a human chain for Ukrainian independence between <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> and <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a>, in <a href="Act%20Zluky">memory of the 1919 unification</a> of the <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a> and the <a href="West%20Ukrainian%20National%20Republic">West Ukrainian National Republic</a>. Citizens came out to the streets and highways, forming live chains by holding hands in support of unity.
On 16 July 1990, the new parliament adopted the <a href="Declaration%20of%20State%20Sovereignty%20of%20Ukraine">Declaration of State Sovereignty of Ukraine</a>. This established the principles of the self-determination, democracy, independence, and the priority of Ukrainian law over Soviet law. A month earlier, a <a href="Declaration%20of%20State%20Sovereignty%20of%20the%20Russian%20Soviet%20Federative%20Socialist%20Republic">similar declaration</a> was adopted by the parliament of the <a href="Russian%20SFSR">Russian SFSR</a>. This started a period of confrontation with the central Soviet authorities. On 2–17 October 1990, the <a href="Revolution%20on%20Granite">Revolution on Granite</a> took place in Ukraine, the main purpose of the action was to prevent the signing of a new union treaty of the USSR. The demands of the students were satisfied by signing a resolution of the Verkhovna Rada, which guaranteed their implementation.
In August 1991, a faction among the Communist leaders of the Soviet Union <a href="Soviet%20coup%20attempt%20of%201991">attempted a coup</a> to remove <a href="Mikhail%20Gorbachev">Mikhail Gorbachev</a> and to restore the Communist party's power. After it failed, on 24 August 1991 the Ukrainian parliament adopted the <a href="Act%20of%20Independence%20of%20Ukraine">Act of Independence</a>.
A <a href="1991%20Ukrainian%20independence%20referendum">referendum</a> and the <a href="1991%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">first presidential elections</a> took place on 1 December 1991. More than 90% of the electorate expressed their support for the Act of Independence, and they elected the chairman of the parliament, <a href="Leonid%20Kravchuk">Leonid Kravchuk</a> as the first <a href="President%20of%20Ukraine">President of Ukraine</a>. At the <a href="Belavezha%20Accords">meeting in Brest</a>, Belarus on 8 December, followed by the <a href="Alma%20Ata">Alma Ata</a> meeting on 21 December, the leaders of Belarus, Russia, and Ukraine formally dissolved the Soviet Union and formed the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Independent%20States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a> (CIS). On 26 December 1991 the Council of Republics of the USSR Supreme Council adapted declaration "In regards to creation of the Commonwealth of Independent States" () which de jure dissolved the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and the <a href="Soviet%20flag">Soviet flag</a> was lowered over <a href="the%20Kremlin">the Kremlin</a>. The Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine did not ratify the accession, i.e. Ukraine has never been a member of the CIS.
Ukraine was initially viewed as having favourable economic conditions in comparison to the other regions of the Soviet Union. However, the country experienced deeper economic slowdown than some of the other <a href="former%20Soviet%20Republics">former Soviet Republics</a>. During the recession, Ukraine lost 60% of its GDP from 1991 to 1999, and suffered five-digit inflation rates. Dissatisfied with the economic conditions, as well as the amounts of crime and <a href="corruption%20in%20Ukraine">corruption in Ukraine</a>, Ukrainians protested and organized strikes.
The Ukrainian economy stabilized by the end of the 1990s. A new currency, the <a href="Ukrainian%20hryvnia">hryvnia</a>, was introduced in 1996. After 2000, the country enjoyed steady <a href="Real%20GDP">real economic growth</a> averaging about seven percent annually. A new <a href="Constitution%20of%20Ukraine">Constitution of Ukraine</a> was adopted under second President <a href="Leonid%20Kuchma">Leonid Kuchma</a> in 1996, which turned Ukraine into a <a href="semi-presidential%20republic">semi-presidential republic</a> and established a stable political system. Kuchma was, however, criticised by opponents for corruption, <a href="electoral%20fraud">electoral fraud</a>, discouraging free speech and concentrating too much power in his office. Ukraine also pursued full nuclear disarmament, giving up the third largest nuclear weapons stockpile in the world and dismantling or removing all strategic bombers on its territory in exchange for various assurances (main article: <a href="Nuclear%20weapons%20and%20Ukraine">Nuclear weapons and Ukraine</a>).
Orange Revolution.
In 2004, <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>, then Prime Minister, was declared the winner of the <a href="2004%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">presidential elections</a>, which had been largely rigged, as the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Ukraine">Supreme Court of Ukraine</a> later ruled. The results caused a public outcry in support of the opposition candidate, <a href="Viktor%20Yushchenko">Viktor Yushchenko</a>, who challenged the outcome. During the tumultuous months of the revolution, candidate Yushchenko <a href="Viktor%20Yushchenko%23TCDD%20poisoning">suddenly became gravely ill</a>, and was soon found by multiple independent physician groups to have been poisoned by <a href="2%2C3%2C7%2C8-Tetrachlorodibenzodioxin">TCDD dioxin</a>. Yushchenko strongly suspected Russian involvement in his poisoning. All of this eventually resulted in the peaceful <a href="Orange%20Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>, bringing Viktor Yushchenko and <a href="Yulia%20Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> to power, while casting Viktor Yanukovych in opposition.
Activists of the Orange Revolution were funded and trained in tactics of political organisation and <a href="nonviolent%20resistance">nonviolent resistance</a> by Western pollsters and professional consultants who were partly funded by Western government and non-government agencies but received most of their funding from domestic sources. According to "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>", the foreign donors included the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20State">U.S. State Department</a> and <a href="United%20States%20Agency%20for%20International%20Development">USAID</a> along with the <a href="National%20Democratic%20Institute%20for%20International%20Affairs">National Democratic Institute for International Affairs</a>, the <a href="International%20Republican%20Institute">International Republican Institute</a>, the <a href="Non-governmental%20organisation">NGO</a> <a href="Freedom%20House">Freedom House</a> and <a href="George%20Soros">George Soros</a>'s <a href="Open%20Society%20Institute">Open Society Institute</a>. The <a href="National%20Endowment%20for%20Democracy">National Endowment for Democracy</a> has supported democracy-building efforts in Ukraine since 1988. Writings on <a href="Nonviolent%20resistance">nonviolent struggle</a> by <a href="Gene%20Sharp">Gene Sharp</a> contributed in forming the strategic basis of the student campaigns.
Russian authorities provided support through advisers such as <a href="Gleb%20Pavlovsky">Gleb Pavlovsky</a>, consulting on blackening the image of Yushchenko through the state media, pressuring state-dependent voters to vote for Yanukovych and on vote-rigging techniques such as multiple "<a href="carousel%20voting">carousel voting</a>" and "dead souls" voting.
Yanukovych returned to power in 2006 as Prime Minister in the <a href="Alliance%20of%20National%20Unity">Alliance of National Unity</a>, until <a href="2007%20Ukrainian%20parliamentary%20election">snap elections in September 2007</a> made Tymoshenko Prime Minister again. Amid the <a href="2008%E2%80%9309%20Ukrainian%20financial%20crisis">2008–09 Ukrainian financial crisis</a> the Ukrainian economy plunged by 15%. <a href="Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine%20gas%20disputes">Disputes with Russia</a> briefly stopped all gas supplies to Ukraine in 2006 and again in 2009, leading to gas shortages in other countries. <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> was <a href="2010%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">elected President in 2010</a> with 48% of votes.
Euromaidan and the Revolution of Dignity.
The <a href="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> (, literally "Eurosquare") protests started in November 2013 after the president, <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>, began moving away from an association agreement that had been in the works with the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> and instead chose to establish closer ties with the Russian Federation. Some Ukrainians took to the streets to show their support for closer ties with Europe.
Meanwhile, in the predominantly Russian-speaking east, a large portion of the population opposed the "Euromaidan" protests, instead supporting the Yanukovych government. Over time, "Euromaidan" came to describe a wave of demonstrations and civil unrest in Ukraine, the scope of which evolved to include calls for the resignation of President Yanukovych and <a href="Second%20Azarov%20Government">his government</a>.
Violence escalated after 16 January 2014 when the government accepted new <a href="Anti-protest%20laws%20in%20Ukraine">Anti-Protest Laws</a>. Violent anti-government demonstrators occupied buildings in the centre of Kyiv, including the Justice Ministry building, and riots left 98 dead with approximately fifteen thousand injured and 100 considered missing from 18 to 20 February. On 21 February, President Yanukovych signed a compromise deal with opposition leaders that promised constitutional changes to restore certain powers to Parliament and called for early elections to be held by December.
However, Members of Parliament voted on 22 February to remove the president and set <a href="2014%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">an election</a> for 25 May to select his replacement. <a href="Petro%20Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a>, running on a pro-European Union platform, won with over fifty percent of the vote, therefore not requiring a run-off election. Upon his election, Poroshenko announced that his immediate priorities would be to take action in the civil unrest in Eastern Ukraine and mend ties with the Russian Federation.
Poroshenko was inaugurated as president on 7 June 2014, as previously announced by his spokeswoman Irina Friz in a low-key ceremony without a celebration on <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>'s <a href="Maidan%20Nezalezhnosti">Maidan Nezalezhnosti</a> (Independence Square, the centre of the <a href="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> protests) for the ceremony. In October 2014 <a href="2014%20Ukrainian%20parliamentary%20election">Parliament elections</a>, <a href="Petro%20Poroshenko%20Bloc%20%26quot%3BSolidarity%26quot%3B">Petro Poroshenko Bloc "Solidarity"</a> won 132 of the 423 contested seats.
Civil unrest, Russian intervention, and annexation of Crimea.
The ousting of Yanukovych prompted Vladimir Putin to begin preparations to annex Crimea on 23 February 2014. Using the Russian naval base at Sevastopol as cover, Putin directed Russian troops and intelligence agents to disarm Ukrainian forces and take control of Crimea. After the troops entered Crimea, a controversial <a href="2014%20Crimean%20referendum">referendum</a> was held on 16 March 2014 and the official result was that 97 percent wished to join with Russia.
On 18 March 2014, Russia and the self-proclaimed Republic of Crimea signed a <a href="Annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation%23Accession%20treaty%20and%20aftermath">treaty of accession of the Republic of Crimea and Sevastopol</a> in the Russian Federation. The <a href="United%20Nations%20General%20Assembly">UN General Assembly</a> immediately responded by passing <a href="United%20Nations%20General%20Assembly%20Resolution%2068/262">resolution 68/262</a> declaring that the referendum was invalid and supporting the territorial integrity of Ukraine; only Russia voted against the resolution. However, it was not enforceable. Attempts to pass enforceable resolutions in the <a href="United%20Nations%20Security%20Council">U.N. Security Council</a> were blocked by Russian <a href="veto">veto</a>es.
Separately, in the <a href="Donetsk">Donetsk</a> and <a href="Luhansk">Luhansk</a> regions, armed men declaring themselves as local militia supported with pro-Russian protesters seized government buildings, police and special police stations in several cities and held unrecognised <a href="2014%20Donbas%20status%20referendums">status referendums</a>. The insurgency was led by Russian emissaries <a href="Igor%20Girkin">Igor Girkin</a> and <a href="Alexander%20Borodai">Alexander Borodai</a> as well as militants from <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, such as <a href="Arseny%20Pavlov">Arseny Pavlov</a>.
Talks in <a href="Geneva">Geneva</a> between the EU, Russia, Ukraine, and the United States yielded a Joint Diplomatic Statement referred to as the <a href="2014%20Geneva%20Pact">2014 Geneva Pact</a> in which the parties requested that all unlawful militias lay down their arms and vacate seized government buildings, and also establish a political dialogue that could lead to more autonomy for Ukraine's regions. When <a href="Petro%20Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a> won the presidential election held on 25 May 2014, he vowed to continue the military operations by the Ukrainian government forces to end the armed insurgency. More than 9,000 people have been killed in the military campaign.
In August 2014, a bilateral commission of leading scholars from the United States and Russia issued the Boisto Agenda indicating a 24-step plan to resolve the crisis in Ukraine. The Boisto Agenda was organized into five imperative categories for addressing the crisis requiring stabilization identified as: (1) Elements of an Enduring, Verifiable Ceasefire; (2) Economic Relations; (3) Social and Cultural Issues; (4) Crimea; and, (5) International Status of Ukraine. In late 2014, Ukraine ratified the <a href="Ukraine%E2%80%93European%20Union%20Association%20Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a>, which Poroshenko described as Ukraine's "first but most decisive step" towards EU membership. Poroshenko also set 2020 as the target for <a href="Ukraine%E2%80%93European%20Union%20relations">EU membership application</a>.
In February 2015, after a summit hosted in <a href="Minsk%2C%20Belarus">Minsk, Belarus</a>, Poroshenko negotiated a ceasefire with the separatist troops. The resulting agreements are known as the <a href="Minsk%20Protocol">Minsk Protocol</a>. This included conditions such as the withdrawal of heavy weaponry from the front line and decentralisation of rebel regions by the end of 2015. It also included conditions such as Ukrainian control of the border with Russia in 2015 and the withdrawal of all foreign troops from Ukrainian territory. The ceasefire began at midnight on 15 February 2015. Participants in this ceasefire also agreed to attend regular meetings to ensure that the agreement is respected.
On 1 January 2016, Ukraine joined the <a href="Deep%20and%20Comprehensive%20Free%20Trade%20Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> with European Union, which aims to modernize and develop Ukraine's economy, governance and rule of law to EU standards and gradually increase integration with the EU <a href="Internal%20market">Internal market</a>. Then, on 11 May 2017 the European Union approved visa-free travel for Ukrainian citizens: this took effect from 11 June entitling Ukrainians to travel to the <a href="Schengen%20area">Schengen area</a> for tourism, family visits and business reasons, with the only document required being a valid biometric passport.
<a href="Arbitration%20Institute%20of%20the%20Stockholm%20Chamber%20of%20Commerce">Arbitration Institute of the Stockholm Chamber of Commerce</a> satisfied the Ukraine's <a href="Naftogaz">Naftogaz's</a> claims for compensation for gas supplies for transit that were not supplied by Russian <a href="Gazprom">Gazprom</a>. According to the decision of the Stockholm Arbitration, Naftogaz has achieved compensation in the amount of 4.63 billion dollars for Gazprom's failure to supply the agreed volumes of gas for transit. According to the results of two arbitration proceedings in <a href="Stockholm">Stockholm</a>, Gazprom has to pay $2.56 billion in favor of Naftogaz.
<a href="Kerch%20Strait%20incident">Kerch Strait incident</a> occurred on 25 November 2018 when the <a href="Russia">Russia</a>n <a href="Federal%20Security%20Service">Federal Security Service</a> (FSB) <a href="Coast%20Guard%20%28Russia%29">coast guard</a> fired upon and captured three <a href="Ukrainian%20Navy">Ukrainian Navy</a> vessels attempting to pass from the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> into the <a href="Sea%20of%20Azov">Sea of Azov</a> through the <a href="Kerch%20Strait">Kerch Strait</a> on their way to the port of <a href="Mariupol">Mariupol</a>.
On 6 January 2019, in <a href="Fener">Fener</a>, a delegation of the <a href="Orthodox%20Church%20of%20Ukraine">Orthodox Church of Ukraine</a> with the participation of President of Ukraine Petro Poroshenko <a href="Autocephaly%20of%20the%20Orthodox%20Church%20of%20Ukraine">received</a> a <a href="Tomos%20%28Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church%29">Tomos</a> on <a href="autocephaly">autocephaly</a>. The Tomos was presented to the head of the OCU, <a href="Epiphanius%20I%20of%20Ukraine">Metropolitan Epiphanius</a>, during a joint liturgy with the <a href="Ecumenical%20Patriarch%20of%20Constantinople">Ecumenical Patriarch</a>. The next day, Tomos was brought to Ukraine for a demonstration at <a href="Saint%20Sophia%20Cathedral%2C%20Kyiv">St. Sophia Cathedral</a>. On 9 January, all members of the <a href="Synod">Synod</a> of the <a href="Ecumenical%20Patriarchate%20of%20Constantinople">Constantinople Orthodox Church</a> signed the Tomos during the scheduled meeting of the Synod.
On 21 February 2019, the Constitution of Ukraine was amended, the norms on the strategic course of Ukraine for membership in the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> and <a href="NATO">NATO</a> are enshrined in the preamble of the Basic Law, three articles and transitional provisions.
The <a href="2019%20Ukrainian%20presidential%20election">2019 Ukrainian presidential election</a> was held on 31 March and 21 April in a <a href="two-round%20system">two-round system</a>. There were a total of 39 candidates for the election on the <a href="ballot">ballot</a>. The <a href="Annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation">2014 annexation</a> of <a href="Crimea">Crimea</a> by <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and the <a href="War%20in%20Donbass">occupation</a> of parts of <a href="Donetsk%20Oblast">Donetsk Oblast</a> and <a href="Luhansk%20Oblast">Luhansk Oblast</a> prevented around 12% of eligible voters from participating in the election. As no candidate received an <a href="absolute%20majority">absolute majority</a> of the vote, a second round was held between the top two candidates, <a href="Volodymyr%20Zelensky">Volodymyr Zelensky</a>, who played the role of Ukraine's president in a popular television comedy and the incumbent president, <a href="Petro%20Poroshenko">Petro Poroshenko</a>, on 21 April 2019. According to the <a href="Central%20Election%20Commission%20%28Ukraine%29">Central Election Commission</a>, Zelensky won the second round with 73.22% of the votes.
<a href="Snap%20election">Snap election</a>s to the Ukrainian parliament were held on 21 July 2019. Originally scheduled to be held at the end of October, these elections were brought forward after newly inaugurated <a href="President%20of%20Ukraine">President</a> <a href="Volodymyr%20Zelensky">Volodymyr Zelensky</a> dissolved parliament on 21 May 2019, during his inauguration. The election result was the one-party majority, a novelty in Ukraine, for President Zelensky's <a href="Servant%20of%20the%20People%20%28political%20party%29">Servant of the People</a> party with 254 seats.
On 7 September 2019, 22 Ukrainian sailors, 2 SBU officers, and 11 Ukrainian Kremlin political prisoners, <a href="Oleg%20Sentsov">Oleh Sentsov</a>, Volodymyr Balukh, Edem Bekirov, Pavlo Hryb, <a href="Mykola%20Karpyuk">Mykola Karpyuk</a>, Stanislav Klykh, <a href="Oleksandr%20Kolchenko">Oleksandr Kolchenko</a>, Yevhen and Artur Panovy, Oleksiy Syzonovych and <a href="Roman%20Sushchenko">Roman Sushchenko</a> returned to Ukraine as a result of a reciprocal release operation.
<a href="Ukraine%20International%20Airlines%20Flight%20752">Ukraine International Airlines Flight 752</a> (PS752) was a scheduled international passenger flight from <a href="Tehran%20Imam%20Khomeini%20International%20Airport">Tehran</a> to <a href="Boryspil%20International%20Airport">Kyiv</a> operated by <a href="Ukraine%20International%20Airlines">Ukraine International Airlines</a> (UIA). On 8 January 2020, the <a href="Boeing%20737-800">Boeing 737-800</a> operating the route was <a href="List%20of%20airliner%20shootdown%20incidents">shot down</a> shortly after takeoff from <a href="Tehran%20Imam%20Khomeini%20International%20Airport">Tehran Imam Khomeini International Airport</a> by the Iranian <a href="Islamic%20Revolutionary%20Guards%20Corps">Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps</a> (IRGC). All 176 passengers and crew were killed.
On 2 March 2020, the first case of COVID-19 infection was confirmed in <a href="Chernivtsi">Chernivtsi</a>. Subsequently, quarantine was imposed, borders were closed and a state of emergency was declared. The epidemic covered all regions of Ukraine. Every day, the Ministry of Health publishes new information about the spread of the pandemic. Due to quarantine restrictions in the country, the economic crisis intensified, the number of officially unemployed increased by 67%.
On 4 March 2020, the <a href="Verkhovna%20Rada">Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine</a> accepted the resignation of the <a href="Honcharuk%20Government">Honcharuk Government</a> and began the formation of the <a href="Shmyhal%20Government">Shmyhal Government</a>.
Geography.
Ukraine is a large country in <a href="Eastern%20Europe">Eastern Europe</a>, lying mostly in the <a href="East%20European%20Plain">East European Plain</a>. It is the <a href="List%20of%20European%20countries%20by%20area">second-largest European country</a>, after Russia. It covers an area of and with a coastline of . It lies between latitudes <a href="44th%20parallel%20north">44°</a> and <a href="53rd%20parallel%20north">53° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="22nd%20meridian%20east">22°</a> and <a href="41st%20meridian%20east">41° E</a>.
The landscape of Ukraine consists mostly of fertile plains (or <a href="steppes">steppes</a>) and plateaus, crossed by rivers such as the <a href="Dnieper%20River">Dnieper</a> (), <a href="Seversky%20Donets">Seversky Donets</a>, <a href="Dniester">Dniester</a> and the <a href="Southern%20Bug">Southern Bug</a> as they flow south into the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> and the smaller <a href="Sea%20of%20Azov">Sea of Azov</a>. To the southwest, the <a href="Danube%20Delta">delta</a> of the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> forms the border with Romania. Ukraine's various regions have diverse geographic features ranging from the highlands to the lowlands. The country's only mountains are the <a href="Carpathian%20Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in the west, of which the highest is the <a href="Hora%20Hoverla">Hora Hoverla</a> at , and the <a href="Crimean%20Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a> on Crimea, in the extreme south along the coast.
Ukraine also has a number of highland regions such as the <a href="Volhynian-Podolian%20Upland">Volyn-Podillia Upland</a> (in the west) and the Near-Dnipro Upland (on the right bank of Dnieper). To the east there are the south-western spurs of the <a href="Central%20Russian%20Upland">Central Russian Upland</a> over which runs the border with the Russian Federation. Near the <a href="Sea%20of%20Azov">Sea of Azov</a> can be found the Donets Ridge and the Near Azov Upland. The <a href="snow%20melt">snow melt</a> from the mountains feeds the rivers, and natural changes in altitude form sudden drops in elevation and give rise to <a href="waterfalls%20of%20Ukraine">waterfalls</a>.
Significant natural resources in Ukraine include iron ore, coal, manganese, natural gas, oil, salt, sulphur, graphite, titanium, magnesium, <a href="kaolin">kaolin</a>, nickel, mercury, timber and an abundance of arable land. Despite this, the country faces a number of major environmental issues such as inadequate supplies of potable water; air and water pollution and deforestation, as well as radiation contamination in the north-east from the <a href="Chernobyl%20disaster">1986 accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant</a>. <a href="Hazardous%20waste">Recycling toxic household waste</a> is still in its infancy in Ukraine.

Climate.
Ukraine has a mostly <a href="temperate%20climate">temperate climate</a>, with the exception of the southern coast of Crimea which has a <a href="subtropical%20climate">subtropical climate</a>.
The climate is influenced by moderately warm, humid air coming from the Atlantic Ocean. Average annual temperatures range from in the north, to in the south.

Biodiversity.
Ukraine contains six terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="Central%20European%20mixed%20forests">Central European mixed forests</a>, <a href="Crimean%20Submediterranean%20forest%20complex">Crimean Submediterranean forest complex</a>, <a href="East%20European%20forest%20steppe">East European forest steppe</a>, <a href="Pannonian%20mixed%20forests">Pannonian mixed forests</a>, <a href="Carpathian%20montane%20conifer%20forests">Carpathian montane conifer forests</a>, and <a href="Pontic%20steppe">Pontic steppe</a>. Ukraine is home to a diverse assemblage of animals, fungi, microorganisms and plants.
Animals.
Ukraine falls into two main zoological areas. One of these areas, in the west of the country, is made up of the borderlands of Europe, where there are species typical of mixed forests, the other is located in eastern Ukraine, where steppe-dwelling species thrive. In the forested areas of the country it is not uncommon to find lynxes, wolves, wild boar and martens, as well as many other similar species.
This is especially true of the <a href="Carpathian%20Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a>, where many predatory mammals make their home, as well as a contingent of brown bears. Around Ukraine's lakes and rivers beavers, otters and mink make their home, whilst in the waters carp, bream and catfish are the most commonly found species of fish. In the central and eastern parts of the country, rodents such as hamsters and gophers are found in large numbers.
Fungi.
More than 6,600 <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="Fungus">fungi</a> (including <a href="lichen">lichen</a>-forming species) have been recorded from Ukraine, but this number is far from complete. The true total number of fungal species occurring in Ukraine, including species not yet recorded, is likely to be far higher, given the generally accepted estimate that only about 7% of all fungi worldwide have so far been discovered. Although the amount of available information is still very small, a first effort has been made to estimate the number of fungal species endemic to Ukraine, and 2,217 such species have been tentatively identified.
Politics.
Ukraine is a republic under a mixed semi-parliamentary <a href="semi-presidential%20system">semi-presidential system</a> with separate <a href="legislative%20branch">legislative</a>, <a href="executive%20branch">executive</a>, and <a href="judicial%20branch">judicial branch</a>es.
Constitution of Ukraine.
With the proclamation of its independence on 24 August 1991, and adoption of a constitution on 28 June 1996, Ukraine became a semi-presidential republic. However, in 2004, deputies introduced changes to the Constitution, which tipped the balance of power in favour of a <a href="parliamentary%20system">parliamentary system</a>. From 2004 to 2010, the legitimacy of the 2004 Constitutional amendments had official sanction, both with the Constitutional Court of Ukraine, and most major political parties. Despite this, on 30 September 2010 the Constitutional Court ruled that the amendments were null and void, forcing a return to the terms of the 1996 Constitution and again making Ukraine's political system more presidential in character.
The ruling on the 2004 Constitutional amendments became a major topic of political discourse. Much of the concern was based on the fact that neither the Constitution of 1996 nor the Constitution of 2004 provided the ability to "undo the Constitution", as the decision of the Constitutional Court would have it, even though the 2004 constitution arguably has an exhaustive list of possible procedures for constitutional amendments (articles 154–159). In any case, the current Constitution could be modified by a vote in Parliament.
On 21 February 2014 an agreement between President Viktor Yanukovych and opposition leaders saw the country return to the 2004 Constitution. The historic agreement, brokered by the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>, followed the <a href="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> protests that began in late November 2013 and culminated in a week of violent clashes in which scores of protesters were killed. In addition to returning the country to the 2004 Constitution, the deal provided for the formation of a coalition government, the calling of early elections, and the release of former Prime Minister <a href="Yulia%20Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> from prison. A day after the agreement was reached the Ukrainian parliament dismissed Yanukovych and installed its speaker <a href="Oleksandr%20Turchynov">Oleksandr Turchynov</a> as interim president and <a href="Arseniy%20Yatsenyuk">Arseniy Yatsenyuk</a> as the <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Ukraine">Prime Minister of Ukraine</a>.
President, parliament and government.
The <a href="President%20of%20Ukraine">President</a> is elected by popular vote for a five-year term and is the formal <a href="head%20of%20state">head of state</a>.
Ukraine's legislative branch includes the 450-seat <a href="unicameral">unicameral</a> parliament, the <a href="Verkhovna%20Rada">Verkhovna Rada</a>.
