The parliament is primarily responsible for the formation of the executive branch and the <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Ministers%20of%20Ukraine">Cabinet of Ministers</a>, headed by the <a href="Prime%20Minister%20of%20Ukraine">Prime Minister</a>. The President retains the authority to nominate the Ministers of the Foreign Affairs and of Defence for parliamentary approval, as well as the power to appoint the <a href="Prosecutor%20General%20of%20Ukraine">Prosecutor General</a> and the head of the <a href="Security%20Service%20of%20Ukraine">Security Service</a>.
Laws, acts of the parliament and the cabinet, presidential decrees, and acts of the <a href="Verkhovna%20Rada%20of%20Crimea">Crimean parliament</a> may be abrogated by the <a href="Constitutional%20Court%20of%20Ukraine">Constitutional Court</a>, should they be found to violate the constitution. Other normative acts are subject to judicial review. The <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20Ukraine">Supreme Court</a> is the main body in the system of courts of general jurisdiction.
Local self-government is officially guaranteed. Local councils and city mayors are popularly elected and exercise control over local budgets. The heads of regional and district administrations are appointed by the President in accordance with the proposals of the Prime Minister.
Courts and law enforcement.
The courts enjoy legal, financial and constitutional freedom guaranteed by Ukrainian law since 2002. Judges are largely well protected from dismissal (except in the instance of gross misconduct). Court justices are appointed by presidential decree for an initial period of five years, after which Ukraine's Supreme Council confirms their positions for life. Although there are still problems, the system is considered to have been much improved since Ukraine's independence in 1991. The Supreme Court is regarded as an independent and impartial body, and has on several occasions ruled against the Ukrainian government. The <a href="World%20Justice%20Project">World Justice Project</a> ranks Ukraine 66 out of 99 countries surveyed in its annual Rule of Law Index.
<a href="Prosecutor">Prosecutor</a>s in Ukraine have greater powers than in most European countries, and according to the <a href="European%20Commission%20for%20Democracy%20through%20Law">European Commission for Democracy through Law</a> 'the role and functions of the Prosecutor's Office is not in accordance with <a href="Council%20of%20Europe">Council of Europe</a> standards". The criminal judicial system maintains an average <a href="conviction%20rate">conviction rate</a> of over 99%, equal to the conviction rate of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, with suspects often being incarcerated for long periods before trial.
On 24 March 2010, President Yanukovych formed an expert group to make recommendations how to "clean up the current mess and adopt a law on court organization". One day later, he stated "We can no longer disgrace our country with such a court system." The criminal judicial system and the prison system of Ukraine remain quite punitive.
Since 1 January 2010 it has been permissible to hold court proceedings in Russian by mutual consent of the parties. Citizens unable to speak <a href="Ukrainian%20language">Ukrainian</a> or Russian may use their native language or the services of a translator. Previously all court proceedings had to be held in Ukrainian.
Law enforcement agencies in Ukraine are organised under the authority of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Internal%20Affairs%20of%20Ukraine">Ministry of Internal Affairs</a>. They consist primarily of the <a href="National%20Police%20of%20Ukraine">national police force</a> and various specialised units and agencies such as the <a href="State%20Border%20Guard%20Service%20of%20Ukraine">State Border Guard</a> and the <a href="Ukrainian%20Sea%20Guard">Coast Guard</a> services. Law enforcement agencies, particularly the police, faced criticism for their heavy handling of the 2004 <a href="Orange%20Revolution">Orange Revolution</a>. Many thousands of police officers were stationed throughout the capital, primarily to dissuade protesters from challenging the state's authority but also to provide a quick reaction force in case of need; most officers were armed. Bloodshed was only avoided when Lt. Gen. <a href="Sergei%20Popkov">Sergei Popkov</a> heeded his colleagues' calls to withdraw.
The Ministry of Internal Affairs is also responsible for the maintenance of the <a href="Security%20Service%20of%20Ukraine">State Security Service</a>; Ukraine's domestic intelligence agency, which has on occasion been accused of acting like a <a href="secret%20police">secret police</a> force serving to protect the country's political elite from media criticism. On the other hand, however, it is widely accepted that members of the service provided vital information about government plans to the leaders of the Orange Revolution to prevent the collapse of the movement.
Foreign relations.
From 1999 to 2001, Ukraine served as a non-permanent member of the <a href="UN%20Security%20Council">UN Security Council</a>. Historically, Soviet Ukraine joined the United Nations in 1945 as one of the original members following a Western compromise with the Soviet Union, which had asked for seats for all 15 of its union republics. Ukraine has consistently supported peaceful, negotiated settlements to disputes. It has participated in the quadripartite talks on the conflict in Moldova and promoted a peaceful resolution to conflict in the post-Soviet state of Georgia. Ukraine also has made a substantial contribution to UN <a href="peacekeeping">peacekeeping</a> operations since 1992.
Ukraine considers Euro-Atlantic integration its primary foreign policy objective, but in practice it has always balanced its relationship with the European Union and the United States with strong ties to Russia. The <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a>'s <a href="Partnership%20and%20Cooperation%20Agreement">Partnership and Cooperation Agreement</a> (PCA) with Ukraine went into force on 1 March 1998. The European Union (EU) has encouraged Ukraine to implement the PCA fully before discussions begin on an association agreement, issued at the EU Summit in December 1999 in <a href="Helsinki">Helsinki</a>, recognizes Ukraine's long-term aspirations but does not discuss association. 
On 31 January 1992, Ukraine joined the then-Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (now the <a href="Organization%20for%20Security%20and%20Cooperation%20in%20Europe">Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe</a> (OSCE)), and on 10 March 1992, it became a member of the <a href="North%20Atlantic%20Cooperation%20Council">North Atlantic Cooperation Council</a>. <a href="Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO%20relations">Ukraine–NATO relations</a> are close and the country has declared interest in eventual membership. This was removed from the government's foreign policy agenda upon election of <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> to the presidency, in 2010. But after February 2014's <a href="2014%20Ukrainian%20revolution">Yanukovych ouster</a> and the (denied by Russia) following Russian military intervention in Ukraine Ukraine renewed its drive for NATO membership. 
Ukraine is the most active member of the <a href="Partnership%20for%20Peace">Partnership for Peace</a> (PfP). All major political parties in Ukraine support full eventual integration into the European Union. The Association Agreement with the EU was expected to be signed and put into effect by the end of 2011, but the process was suspended by 2012 because of the political developments of that time. The Association Agreement between Ukraine and the European Union was signed in 2014.
Ukraine long had close ties with all its neighbours, but <a href="Russia%E2%80%93Ukraine%20relations">Russia–Ukraine relations</a> rapidly deteriorated in 2014 by the <a href="Annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation">annexation of Crimea</a>, energy dependence and payment disputes. There are also some tensions with <a href="Poland">Poland</a> and <a href="Hungary">Hungary</a>.
The <a href="Deep%20and%20Comprehensive%20Free%20Trade%20Area">Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area</a> (DCFTA), which entered into force in January 2016 following the ratification of the <a href="Ukraine%E2%80%93European%20Union%20Association%20Agreement">Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement</a>, formally integrates Ukraine into the <a href="European%20Single%20Market">European Single Market</a> and the <a href="European%20Economic%20Area">European Economic Area</a>. Ukraine receives further support and assistance for its <a href="Future%20enlargement%20of%20the%20European%20Union">EU-accession</a> aspirations from the International Visegrád Fund of the <a href="Visegr%C3%A1d%20Group">Visegrád Group</a> that consists of <a href="Central%20Europe">Central Europe</a>an <a href="Member%20state%20of%20the%20European%20Union">EU members</a> the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary and Slovakia.
On 19 May 2018, Poroshenko signed a decree, which put into effect the decision of the National Security and Defense Council on the final termination of Ukraine's participation in the statutory bodies of the <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Independent%20States">Commonwealth of Independent States</a>. As of February 2019, Ukraine has minimized its participation in the Commonwealth of Independent States to a critical minimum and has effectively completed its withdrawal. The Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine did not ratify the accession, i.e. Ukraine has never been a member of the CIS.
On 28 July 2020, in <a href="Lublin">Lublin</a>, <a href="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a> and Ukraine created the <a href="Lublin%20Triangle">Lublin Triangle</a> initiative, which aims to create further cooperation between the three historical countries of the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a> and further Ukraine's integration and accession to the <a href="EU">EU</a> and <a href="NATO">NATO</a>.
On 17 May 2021, the <a href="Association%20Trio">Association Trio</a> was formed by signing a joint memorandum between the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20of%20Georgia">Foreign Ministers of Georgia</a>, <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20and%20European%20Integration%20of%20Moldova">Moldova</a> and <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Ukraine%29">Ukraine</a>. Association Trio is tripartite format for the enhanced cooperation, coordination, and dialogue between the three countries (that have signed the Association Agreement with the EU) with the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> on issues of common interest related to <a href="European%20integration">European integration</a>, enhancing cooperation within the framework of the <a href="Eastern%20Partnership">Eastern Partnership</a>, and committing to the prospect of joining the European Union. As of 2021, Ukraine is preparing to formally apply for <a href="European%20Union">EU</a> membership in 2024, in order to join the European Union in the 2030s.
Armed forces.
After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, Ukraine inherited a 780,000-man military force on its territory, equipped with the third-largest <a href="nuclear%20weapons%20and%20Ukraine">nuclear weapons arsenal</a> in the world. In May 1992, Ukraine signed the <a href="Lisbon%20Protocol">Lisbon Protocol</a> in which the country agreed to give up all nuclear weapons to Russia for disposal and to join the <a href="Nuclear%20Non-Proliferation%20Treaty">Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty</a> as a non-nuclear weapon state. Ukraine ratified the treaty in 1994, and by 1996 the country became free of nuclear weapons.
Ukraine took consistent steps toward reduction of conventional weapons. It signed the <a href="Treaty%20on%20Conventional%20Armed%20Forces%20in%20Europe">Treaty on Conventional Armed Forces in Europe</a>, which called for reduction of tanks, artillery, and armoured vehicles (army forces were reduced to 300,000). The country plans to convert the current <a href="conscript">conscript</a>-based military into a professional <a href="volunteer%20military">volunteer military</a>.
Ukraine has been playing an increasingly larger role in peacekeeping operations. On Friday 3 January 2014, the Ukrainian frigate "Hetman Sagaidachniy" joined the European Union's counter piracy <a href="Operation%20Atalanta">Operation Atalanta</a> and will be part of the EU Naval Force off the coast of <a href="Somalia">Somalia</a> for two months. Ukrainian troops are deployed in <a href="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> as part of the <a href="Polish-Ukrainian%20Peace%20Force%20Battalion">Ukrainian-Polish Battalion</a>. 
A Ukrainian unit was deployed in <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, as part of <a href="United%20Nations%20Interim%20Force%20in%20Lebanon">UN Interim Force</a> enforcing the mandated ceasefire agreement. There was also a maintenance and training battalion deployed in <a href="Sierra%20Leone">Sierra Leone</a>. In 2003–05, a Ukrainian unit was deployed as part of the <a href="Multinational%20force%20in%20Iraq">Multinational force in Iraq</a> under Polish command. The total Ukrainian armed forces deployment around the world is 562 servicemen.
Military units of other states participate in multinational military exercises with Ukrainian forces in Ukraine regularly, including <a href="U.S.%20military">U.S. military</a> forces.
Following independence, Ukraine declared itself a neutral state. The country has had a limited military partnership with Russian Federation, other CIS countries and a <a href="Partnership%20for%20Peace">partnership with NATO</a> since 1994. In the 2000s, the government was leaning towards NATO, and a deeper cooperation with the alliance was set by the NATO-Ukraine Action Plan signed in 2002. It was later agreed that the question of joining NATO should be answered by a national referendum at some point in the future. Recently deposed <a href="Ukrainian%20President">President</a> <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> considered the current level of co-operation between <a href="Ukraine%E2%80%93NATO%20relations">Ukraine and NATO</a> sufficient, and was against Ukraine joining NATO. During the <a href="2008%20Bucharest%20summit">2008 Bucharest summit</a>, NATO declared that Ukraine would eventually become a member of NATO when it meets the criteria for the accession.
Administrative divisions.
The system of Ukrainian subdivisions reflects the country's status as a <a href="unitary%20state">unitary state</a> (as stated in the country's constitution) with unified legal and <a href="Local%20government">administrative</a> regimes for each unit.
Including Sevastopol and the Autonomous Republic of Crimea that were annexed by the Russian Federation in 2014, Ukraine consists of 27 regions: twenty-four <a href="oblast">oblast</a>s (provinces), one <a href="autonomous%20republic">autonomous republic</a> (<a href="Autonomous%20Republic%20of%20Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a>), and two cities of special status—<a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, the capital, and <a href="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a>. The 24 oblasts and Crimea are subdivided into 136 (districts) and city municipalities of regional significance, or second-level administrative units.
<a href="Populated%20places%20in%20Ukraine">Populated places in Ukraine</a> are split into two categories: urban and rural. Urban populated places are split further into cities and <a href="urban-type%20settlement">urban-type settlement</a>s (a Soviet administrative invention), while rural populated places consist of villages and settlements (a generally used term). All cities have certain degree of self-rule depending on their significance such as national significance (as in the case of Kyiv and Sevastopol), regional significance (within each oblast or autonomous republic) or district significance (all the rest of cities). A city's significance depends on several factors such as its population, socio-economic and historical importance, infrastructure and others.
Economy.
Ukraine has a lower-middle income economy, which is the <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20GDP%20%28nominal%29">55th largest in the world</a> by nominal GDP, and the <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20GDP%20%28PPP%29">40th largest</a> by <a href="purchasing%20power%20parity">PPP</a>. It is one of the world's largest <a href="Grain%20trade">grain exporters</a>. However, Ukraine remains among the <a href="List%20of%20sovereign%20states%20in%20Europe%20by%20GDP%20%28nominal%29%20per%20capita">poorest in Europe</a> and <a href="Corruption%20in%20Ukraine">most severely corrupt</a> countries in the continent. According to the IMF, Ukraine's GDP per capita by PPP is $14,146.
In 2021, the average nominal salary in Ukraine reached its highest level at <a href="Ukrainian%20hryvnia">₴</a>14,282 (or <a href="United%20States%20dollar">$</a>525) per month. In 2018, Ukraine's median wealth per adult was $40, one of the lowest in the world. Approximately 1.1% of Ukrainians lived <a href="Poverty%20by%20country">below the national poverty line</a> in 2019. Unemployment in Ukraine was 4.5% in 2019. In 2019 5–15% of the Ukrainian population were categorized as middle class. , Ukraine's <a href="government%20debt">government debt</a> is roughly 52% of its nominal GDP.
Ukraine produces nearly all types of transportation vehicles and <a href="State%20Space%20Agency%20of%20Ukraine">spacecraft</a>. <a href="Antonov">Antonov</a> airplanes and <a href="KrAZ">KrAZ</a> trucks are exported to many countries. The majority of Ukrainian exports are marketed to the <a href="European%20Union">European Union</a> and <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Independent%20States">CIS</a>. Since independence, Ukraine has maintained its own space agency, the <a href="State%20Space%20Agency%20of%20Ukraine">State Space Agency of Ukraine</a> (SSAU). Ukraine became an active participant in scientific space exploration and remote sensing missions. Between 1991 and 2007, Ukraine has launched six self made <a href="satellites">satellites</a> and 101 <a href="launch%20vehicle">launch vehicle</a>s, and continues to design spacecraft.
Ukraine produces and processes its own natural gas and <a href="petroleum">petroleum</a>. However, the country imports most of its energy supplies, and 80% of Ukraine's natural gas supplies are imported, mainly from Russia.
Corporations.
Ukraine has a very large heavy-industry base and is one of the largest refiners of metallurgical products in Eastern Europe. However, the country is also well known for its production of high-technological goods and transport products, such as <a href="Antonov">Antonov</a> aircraft and various private and commercial vehicles. The country's largest and most competitive firms are components of the <a href="PFTS%20index">PFTS index</a>, traded on the <a href="PFTS%20Ukraine%20Stock%20Exchange">PFTS Ukraine Stock Exchange</a>.
Well-known Ukrainian brands include <a href="Naftogaz%20Ukrainy">Naftogaz Ukrainy</a>, <a href="AvtoZAZ">AvtoZAZ</a>, <a href="PrivatBank">PrivatBank</a>, <a href="Roshen">Roshen</a>, <a href="Yuzhmash">Yuzhmash</a>, <a href="Nemiroff">Nemiroff</a>, <a href="Motor%20Sich">Motor Sich</a>, <a href="Khortytsia%20%28company%29">Khortytsia</a>, <a href="Kyivstar">Kyivstar</a> and <a href="Aerosvit">Aerosvit</a>.
Transport.
In total, Ukrainian paved roads stretch for . Major routes, marked with the letter 'M' for 'International' "(<a href="Ukrainian%20Language">Ukrainian</a>: Міжнародний"), extend nationwide and connect all major cities of Ukraine, and provide cross-border routes to the country's neighbours. There are only two true <a href="motorway">motorway</a> standard highways in Ukraine; a stretch of motorway from <a href="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a> to <a href="Dnipro">Dnipro</a> and a section of the M03 which extends from <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> to <a href="Boryspil">Boryspil</a>, where the city's <a href="Boryspil%20Airport">international airport</a> is located.
<a href="Rail%20transport%20in%20Ukraine">Rail transport in Ukraine</a> connects all major urban areas, port facilities and <a href="Manufacturing">industrial centres</a> with neighbouring countries. The heaviest concentration of <a href="railway%20track">railway track</a> is the <a href="Donbas">Donbas</a> region of Ukraine. Although <a href="rail%20freight%20transport">rail freight transport</a> fell in the 1990s, Ukraine is still one of the <a href="rail%20usage%20statistics%20by%20country">world's highest rail users</a>.
The total amount of railroad track in Ukraine extends for , of which was electrified in the 2000s. The state has a monopoly on the provision of passenger rail transport, and all trains, other than those with cooperation of other foreign companies on international routes, are operated by its company '<a href="Ukrainian%20Railways">Ukrzaliznytsia</a>.
<a href="Boryspil%20International%20Airport">Kyiv Boryspil</a> is Ukraine's largest international airport. It has three main passenger terminals and is the base for the country's flag carrier, <a href="Ukraine%20International%20Airlines">Ukraine International Airlines</a>. Other large airports in the country include those in <a href="Kharkiv%20International%20Airport">Kharkiv</a>, <a href="Lviv%20International%20Airport">Lviv</a> and <a href="Donetsk%20International%20Airport">Donetsk</a> (now destroyed), whilst those in <a href="Dnipro%20International%20Airport">Dnipro</a> and <a href="Odessa%20International%20Airport">Odessa</a> have plans for terminal upgrades in the near future. In addition to its flag carrier, Ukraine has a number of airlines including <a href="Windrose%20Airlines">Windrose Airlines</a>, <a href="Dniproavia">Dniproavia</a>, <a href="Azur%20Air%20Ukraine">Azur Air Ukraine</a>, and <a href="AtlasGlobal%20Ukraine">AtlasGlobal Ukraine</a>. <a href="Antonov%20Airlines">Antonov Airlines</a>, a subsidiary of the Antonov Aerospace Design Bureau is the only operator of the world's largest fixed wing aircraft, the <a href="An-225">An-225</a>.
International maritime travel is mainly provided through the <a href="Port%20of%20Odessa">Port of Odessa</a>, from where ferries sail regularly to <a href="Istanbul">Istanbul</a>, <a href="Varna%2C%20Bulgaria">Varna</a> and <a href="Haifa">Haifa</a>. The largest ferry company presently operating these routes is <a href="UkrFerry">Ukrferry</a>.
Power generation.
Ukraine has been a net <a href="Electricity%20market">energy exporting</a> country, for example in 2011, 3.3% of electricity produced were exported, but also one of Europe's largest <a href="Electricity">energy</a> consumers. , 47.6% of total electricity generation was from <a href="nuclear%20power">nuclear power</a>
The largest <a href="nuclear%20power%20plant">nuclear power plant</a> in Europe, the <a href="Zaporizhzhia%20Nuclear%20Power%20Plant">Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant</a>, is located in Ukraine. Until the 2010s, all of Ukraine's nuclear fuel was coming from Russia. In 2008 <a href="Westinghouse%20Electric%20Company">Westinghouse Electric Company</a> won a five-year contract selling nuclear fuel to three Ukrainian reactors starting in 2011.
Following <a href="Euromaidan">Euromaidan</a> then President <a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a> introduced a ban on <a href="Rosatom">Rosatom</a> nuclear fuel shipments to Europe via Ukraine, which was in effect from 28 January until 6 March 2014. By 2016, Russia's share was down to 55 percent, <a href="Westinghouse%20Electric%20Company">Westinghouse</a> supplying nuclear fuel for six of Ukraine's <a href="VVER-1000">VVER-1000</a> nuclear reactors. After the Russian annexation of Crimea in April 2014, the National Nuclear Energy Generating Company of Ukraine <a href="Energoatom">Energoatom</a> and Westinghouse extended the contract for fuel deliveries through 2020.
<a href="Coal">Coal</a> and <a href="natural%20gas">gas</a>-fired <a href="thermal%20power%20station">thermal power station</a>s and <a href="hydro%20power">hydroelectricity</a> are the second- and third-largest kinds of power generation in the country.
Information Technology.
According to A.T. Kearney Global Services Location Index, Ukraine ranks 24th among the best outsourcing locations, and is among the top 20 offshore services locations in EMEA, according to Gartner. In the first six months of 2017, the volume of export of computer and information services reached $1.256 billion, which is an 18.3% increase compared to the same period in 2016. The IT industry ranks third in the export structure of Ukraine after agro-industry and metallurgy.
Ukraine's IT sector employs close to 100,000 workers, including 50,000 software developers. This number is expected to surpass the 200,000 mark by 2020. There are over 1,000 IT companies in Ukraine. In 2017, 13 of them made it to the list of 100 best outsourcing service providers in the world. More than 100 multinational tech companies have R&D labs in Ukraine.
Ukraine ranks first worldwide in the number of <a href="C%2B%2B">C++</a> and <a href="Unity3D">Unity3D</a> developers, and second in the number of <a href="JavaScript">JavaScript</a>, Scala, and Magento engineers. Seventy-eight percent of Ukrainian tech workers report having an intermediate or higher level of English proficiency.
Tourism.
In 2007 Ukraine occupied 8th place in Europe by the number of tourists visiting, according to the <a href="World%20Tourism%20Organization">World Tourism Organization</a> <a href="World%20Tourism%20rankings">rankings</a>. Ukraine has numerous tourist attractions: mountain ranges suitable for <a href="skiing">skiing</a>, hiking and fishing: the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a> coastline as a popular summer destination; <a href="nature%20reserve">nature reserve</a>s of different <a href="ecosystem">ecosystem</a>s; churches, <a href="castle">castle</a> ruins and other architectural and park landmarks; various <a href="outdoor%20activity">outdoor activity</a> points. <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a>, <a href="Odessa">Odessa</a> and <a href="Kamyanets-Podilskyi">Kamyanets-Podilskyi</a> are Ukraine's principal tourist centres each offering many historical landmarks as well as formidable <a href="hospitality">hospitality</a> infrastructure. Tourism used to be the mainstay of Crimea's economy but there has been a major fall in visitor numbers following the Russian annexation in 2014.
The <a href="Seven%20Wonders%20of%20Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a> and <a href="Seven%20Natural%20Wonders%20of%20Ukraine">Seven Natural Wonders of Ukraine</a> are the selection of the most important landmarks of Ukraine, chosen by the general public through an Internet-based vote.
Demographics.
, Ukraine has an estimated population of 41.4 million, and is the <a href="List%20of%20European%20countries%20by%20population">eighth-most populous country</a> in Europe. It is a <a href="Urbanization%20by%20country">heavily urbanized country</a>, and its industrial regions in the east and southeast are the most densely populated—about 67% of its total population lives in urban areas. Ukraine has a <a href="list%20of%20countries%20by%20population%20density">population density</a> of 69.49 inhabitants per square kilometre (180 per square mile), and the overall <a href="List%20of%20countries%20by%20life%20expectancy">life expectancy in the country</a> at birth is 73 years (68 years for males and 77.8 years for females).
Following the <a href="dissolution%20of%20the%20Soviet%20Union">dissolution of the Soviet Union</a>, Ukraine's population hit a peak of roughly 52 million in 1993. However, due to its <a href="death%20rate">death rate</a> exceeding its <a href="birth%20rate">birth rate</a>, mass emigration, poor living conditions, and low-quality health care, the total population decreased by 6.6 million, or 12.8% from the same year to 2014.
According to the <a href="Ukrainian%20Census%20%282001%29">2001 census</a>, ethnic <a href="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> make up roughly 78% of the population, while <a href="Russians">Russians</a> are the largest minority, at some 17.3% of the population. Small minority populations include: <a href="Belarusians">Belarusians</a> (0.6%), <a href="Moldovans">Moldovans</a> (0.5%), <a href="Crimean%20Tatars">Crimean Tatars</a> (0.5%), <a href="Bulgarians">Bulgarians</a> (0.4%), <a href="Hungarians">Hungarians</a> (0.3%), <a href="Romanians">Romanians</a> (0.3%), <a href="Poles">Poles</a> (0.3%), <a href="Jews">Jews</a> (0.3%), <a href="Armenians">Armenians</a> (0.2%), <a href="Greeks">Greeks</a> (0.2%) and <a href="Tatars">Tatars</a> (0.2%). It is also estimated that there are about 10–40,000 <a href="Koreans">Koreans</a> in Ukraine, who live mostly in the south of the country, belonging to the historical <a href="Koryo-saram">Koryo-saram</a> group.
Language.
According to the constitution, the <a href="official%20language">state language</a> of Ukraine is Ukrainian. Russian is widely spoken, especially in eastern and southern Ukraine. According to the <a href="Ukrainian%20Census%20%282001%29">2001 census</a>, 67.5 percent of the population declared Ukrainian as their native language and 29.6 percent declared Russian. Most native Ukrainian speakers know Russian as a second language. Russian was the "de facto" dominant language of the Soviet Union but Ukrainian also held official status and in the schools of the <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> learning Ukrainian was mandatory.
Effective in August 2012, <a href="Legislation%20on%20languages%20in%20Ukraine">a new law on regional languages</a> entitles any local language spoken by at least a 10 percent minority be declared official within that area. Russian was within weeks declared as a regional language in several southern and eastern <a href="Oblasts%20of%20Ukraine">oblasts</a> (provinces) and cities. Russian can now be used in these cities'/oblasts' administrative office work and documents.
On 23 February 2014, following the <a href="2014%20Ukrainian%20revolution">2014 Ukrainian revolution</a>, the <a href="Ukrainian%20Parliament">Ukrainian Parliament</a> voted to repeal the law on regional languages, making Ukrainian the sole state language at all levels; however, the repeal was not signed by acting <a href="Oleksandr%20Turchynov">President Turchynov</a> or by President Poroshenko. In February 2019, the law allowing for regional languages was found unconstitutional.
Ukrainian is mainly spoken in western and central Ukraine. In western Ukraine, Ukrainian is also the dominant language in cities (such as <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a>). In central Ukraine, Ukrainian and Russian are both equally used in cities, with Russian being more common in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, while Ukrainian is the dominant language in rural communities. In eastern and southern Ukraine, Russian is primarily used in cities, and Ukrainian is used in rural areas. These details result in a significant difference across different survey results, as even a small restating of a question switches responses of a significant group of people. <a href="Hungarian%20language">Hungarian</a> is spoken in the <a href="Zakarpattia%20Oblast">Zakarpattia Oblast</a>.
For a large part of the Soviet era, the number of Ukrainian speakers declined from generation to generation, and by the mid-1980s, the usage of the Ukrainian language in public life had decreased significantly. Following independence, the government of Ukraine began restoring the image and usage of Ukrainian language through a policy of <a href="Ukrainisation">Ukrainisation</a>. Today, most foreign films and TV programs, including Russian ones, are subtitled or dubbed in Ukrainian. Ukraine's 2017 <a href="Education%20in%20Ukraine">education law</a> bars primary education in public schools in grade five and up in any language but Ukrainian. The "<a href="Ukrainian%20Independent%20Information%20Agency">Unian</a>" reported that "A ban on the use of cultural products, namely movies, books, songs, etc., in the Russian language in the public has been introduced" in the <a href="Lviv%20Oblast">Lviv Oblast</a> in September 2018.
According to the Constitution of the <a href="Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a>, Ukrainian is the only state language of the republic. However, the republic's constitution specifically recognises Russian as the language of the majority of its population and guarantees its usage 'in all spheres of public life'. Similarly, the <a href="Crimean%20Tatar%20language">Crimean Tatar language</a> (the language of 12 percent of population of Crimea) is guaranteed a special state protection as well as the 'languages of other ethnicities'. Russian speakers constitute an overwhelming majority of the Crimean population (77 percent), with Crimean Tatar speakers 11.4 percent and Ukrainian speakers comprising just 10.1 percent. But in everyday life the majority of Crimean Tatars and Ukrainians in Crimea use Russian.
Religion.
Ukraine has the world's <a href="Eastern%20Orthodoxy%20by%20country">second-largest Eastern Orthodox population</a>, after <a href="Russia">Russia</a>. A 2021 survey conducted by the <a href="Kyiv%20International%20Institute%20of%20Sociology">Kyiv International Institute of Sociology</a> found that 82% of Ukrainians declared themselves to be religious, while 7% were <a href="atheists">atheists</a>, and a further 11% found it difficult to answer the question. The level of religiosity in Ukraine was reported to be the highest in <a href="Western%20Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> (91%), and the lowest in the <a href="Donbas">Donbas</a> (57%) and <a href="Eastern%20Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> (56%).
In 2021, 82% of Ukrainians were Christians; out of which 72.7% declared themselves to be <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox%20Church">Orthodox</a>, 8.8% <a href="Ukrainian%20Greek%20Catholic%20Church">Greek Rite Catholics</a>, 2.3% <a href="Protestantism">Protestants</a> and 0.9% <a href="Latin%20Church">Latin Rite Catholics</a>. 2.3% other <a href="Christians">Christians</a>. <a href="Judaism">Judaism</a>, <a href="Islam">Islam</a> and <a href="Hinduism">Hinduism</a> were the religions of 0.2% of the population each. According to the study by <a href="SOCIS">Kyiv International Institute of Sociology</a>, roughly 58.3% of the Ukrainian Orthodox population were members of the <a href="Orthodox%20Church%20of%20Ukraine">Orthodox Church of Ukraine</a>, and 25.4% were members of the <a href="Ukrainian%20Orthodox%20Church%20%28Moscow%20Patriarchate%29">Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Moscow Patriarchate</a>.
According to a 2018 survey by the Razumkov Centre, 9.4% of Ukrainians were <a href="Ukrainian%20Greek%20Catholic%20Church">Byzantine Rite Catholics</a> and 0.8% were <a href="Catholic%20Church">Latin Rite Catholics</a>. <a href="Protestants%20in%20Ukraine">Protestants</a> are a growing community in Ukraine, who made up 1.9% of the population in 2016, but rose to 2.2% of the population in 2018.
Health.
Ukraine's healthcare system is state subsidised and freely available to all Ukrainian citizens and registered residents. However, it is not compulsory to be treated in a state-run hospital as a number of private medical complexes do exist nationwide. The public sector employs most healthcare professionals, with those working for private medical centres typically also retaining their state employment as they are mandated to provide care at public health facilities on a regular basis.
All of Ukraine's medical service providers and hospitals are subordinate to the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Healthcare%20%28Ukraine%29">Ministry of Healthcare</a>, which provides oversight and scrutiny of general medical practice as well as being responsible for the day-to-day administration of the healthcare system. Despite this, standards of hygiene and patient-care have fallen.
Hospitals in Ukraine are organised along the same lines as most European nations, according to the regional administrative structure; as a result most towns have their own hospital "(Міська Лікарня)" and many also have district hospitals "(Районна Лікарня)". Larger and more specialised medical complexes tend only to be found in major cities, with some even more specialised units located only in the capital, <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>. However, all <a href="Administrative%20divisions%20of%20Ukraine">oblasts</a> have their own network of general hospitals which are able to deal with almost all medical problems and are typically equipped with major trauma centres; such hospitals are called 'regional hospitals' "(Обласна Лікарня)".
Ukraine faces a number of major public health issues and is considered to be in a demographic crisis because of its high death rate and low birth rate (the Ukrainian birth rate is 11 births/1,000 population, and the death rate is 16.3 deaths/1,000 population). A factor contributing to the high death rate is a high <a href="mortality%20rate">mortality rate</a> among working-age males from preventable causes such as <a href="alcohol%20poisoning">alcohol poisoning</a> and smoking. In 2008, the country's population was one of the fastest declining in the world at −5% growth. The UN warned that Ukraine's population could fall by as much as 10 million by 2050 if trends did not improve. In addition, obesity, systemic high blood pressure and the HIV endemic are all major challenges facing the Ukrainian healthcare system.
As of March 2009 the <a href="Ukrainian%20government">Ukrainian government</a> is reforming the health care system, by the creation of a national network of <a href="family%20doctor">family doctor</a>s and improvements in the <a href="Emergency%20medical%20services">medical emergency services</a>. In November 2009, former <a href="Ukrainian%20Prime%20Minister">Prime Minister</a> <a href="Yulia%20Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a> proposed introducing a public healthcare system based on health insurance in the spring of 2010.
Active reformation of Ukraine's healthcare system was initiated right after the appointment of <a href="Ulana%20Suprun">Ulana Suprun</a> as a head of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Healthcare%20%28Ukraine%29">Ministry of Healthcare</a>. Assisted by deputy Pavlo Kovtoniuk, Suprun first changed the distribution of finances in healthcare. Funds must follow the patient. General practitioners will provide basic care for patients. The patient will have the right to choose one. Emergency medical service is considered to be fully funded by the state. <a href="Emergency%20Medicine%20Reform%20in%20Ukraine%20since%202016">Emergency Medicine Reform</a> is also an important part of the healthcare reform. In addition, patients who suffer from chronic diseases, which cause a high toll of disability and mortality, are provided with free or low-price medicine.
The <a href="Ukrainian%20Red%20Cross%20Society">Ukrainian Red Cross Society</a> was established in April 1918 in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> as an independent humanitarian society of the <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukrainian People's Republic</a>. Its immediate tasks were to help refugees and prisoners of war, care for handicapped people and orphaned children, fight famine and epidemics, support and organize sick quarters, hospitals and public canteens. At present, society involves more than 6.3 million supporters and activists. Its Visiting Nurses Service has 3,200 qualified nurses. 
The organization takes part in more than 40 humanitarian programmes all over Ukraine, which are mostly funded by public donation and corporate partnerships. By its own estimates, the Society annually provides services to more than 105,000 lonely, elderly people, about 23,000 people disabled during the Second World War and handicapped workers, more than 25,000 war veterans, and more than 8,000 adults handicapped since childhood. Assistance for orphaned and disabled children is also rendered.
Education.
According to the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Ukraine">Ukrainian constitution</a>, access to free education is granted to all citizens. Complete general secondary education is compulsory in the state schools which constitute the overwhelming majority. Free higher education in state and communal educational establishments is provided on a competitive basis. There is also a small number of accredited private secondary and higher education institutions.
Because of the Soviet Union's emphasis on total access of education for all citizens, which continues today, the <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> is an estimated 99.4%. Since 2005, an eleven-year school programme has been replaced with a twelve-year one: primary education takes four years to complete (starting at age six), middle education (secondary) takes five years to complete; upper secondary then takes three years. In the 12th grade, students take Government tests, which are also referred to as school-leaving exams. These tests are later used for university admissions.
The first higher education institutions (HEIs) emerged in Ukraine during the late 16th and early 17th centuries. The first Ukrainian higher education institution was the <a href="Ostroh%20Academy">Ostrozka School</a>, or Ostrozkiy Greek-Slavic-Latin Collegium, similar to Western European higher education institutions of the time. Established in 1576 in the town of <a href="Ostroh">Ostrog</a>, the Collegium was the first higher education institution in the <a href="East%20Slavic%20peoples">Eastern Slavic</a> territories. The oldest university was the <a href="National%20University%20of%20Kyiv-Mohyla%20Academy">Kyiv Mohyla Academy</a>, first established in 1632 and in 1694 officially recognised by the government of <a href="Imperial%20Russia">Imperial Russia</a> as a higher education institution.
Among the oldest is also the <a href="Lviv%20University">Lviv University</a>, founded in 1661. More higher education institutions were set up in the 19th century, beginning with universities in <a href="Kharkiv%20University">Kharkiv</a> (1805), <a href="Taras%20Shevchenko%20National%20University%20of%20Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (1834), <a href="Odessa%20University">Odessa</a> (1865) and <a href="Chernivtsi%20University">Chernivtsi</a> (1875) and a number of professional higher education institutions, e.g.: <a href="Nizhyn%20Pedagogical%20University">Nizhyn Historical and Philological Institute</a> (originally established as the Gymnasium of Higher Sciences in 1805), a Veterinary Institute (1873) and a <a href="Kharkiv%20Polytechnical%20Institute">Technological Institute</a> (1885) in <a href="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a>, a <a href="Igor%20Sikorsky%20Kyiv%20Polytechnic%20Institute">Polytechnic Institute</a> in <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> (1898) and a Higher Mining School (1899) in <a href="Dnipro">Katerynoslav</a>. Rapid growth followed in the <a href="Ukrainian%20Soviet%20Socialist%20Republic">Soviet</a> period. By 1988 a number of higher education institutions increased to 146 with over 850,000 students. Most HEIs established after 1990 are those owned by private organisations.
The Ukrainian higher education system comprises higher educational establishments, <a href="scientific">scientific</a> and <a href="methodological">methodological</a> facilities under national, <a href="municipal%20government">municipal</a> and self-governing bodies in charge of education. The organisation of higher education in Ukraine is built up in accordance with the structure of education of the world's higher <a href="developed%20countries">developed countries</a>, as is defined by <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> and the UN.
Ukraine has more than 800 higher-education institutions and in 2010 the number of graduates reached 654,700 people.
Ukraine produces the fourth largest number of <a href="Tertiary%20education">post-secondary graduates</a> in Europe, while being ranked seventh in population. <a href="Higher%20education%20in%20Ukraine">Higher education</a> is either state funded or private. Students that study at state expense receive a standard scholarship if their average marks at the end-of-term exams and differentiated test suffice; this rule may be different in some universities. For highest grades, the scholarship is increased by 25%. For most students the government subsidy is not sufficient to cover their basic living expenses.
Most universities provide subsidised housing for out-of-city students. It is common for libraries to supply required books for all registered students. Ukrainian universities confer two degrees: the bachelor's degree (4 years) and the master's degree (5–6th year), in accordance with the <a href="Bologna%20process">Bologna process</a>. Historically, <a href="Specialist%20degree">Specialist degree</a> (usually 5 years) is still also granted; it was the only degree awarded by universities in the Soviet times.
The Law of Ukraine "On Higher Education" came into force on 6 September 2014. It was approved in Ukrainian Parliament on 1 July 2014. The main changes in the system of higher education: a separate collegiate body to monitor the quality of education was established (Ukrainian: Національне агентство із забезпечення якості вищої освіти); each higher education institution has the right to implement its own educational and research programs; role of the student government was increased; higher education institution has the right to freely administer own revenues; five following types of higher education qualifications were established: Junior Bachelor, Bachelor, Master, Doctor of Philosophy (PhD) and Doctor of Science; load on lecturers and students was reduced; academic mobility for faculty and students etc.
Regional differences.
<a href="Ukrainian%20language">Ukrainian</a> is the dominant language in <a href="Western%20Ukraine">Western Ukraine</a> and in <a href="Central%20Ukraine">Central Ukraine</a>, while <a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a> is the dominant language in the cities of <a href="Eastern%20Ukraine">Eastern Ukraine</a> and <a href="Southern%20Ukraine">Southern Ukraine</a>. In the <a href="Ukrainian%20SSR">Ukrainian SSR</a> schools, learning <a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a> was mandatory; in modern Ukraine, schools with Ukrainian as the language of instruction offer classes in Russian and in the other minority languages.
On the <a href="Russian%20language%20in%20Ukraine">Russian language</a>, on <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="Ukrainian%20nationalism">Ukrainian nationalism</a>, opinion in Eastern Ukraine and Southern Ukraine tends to be the exact opposite of those in Western Ukraine; while opinions in Central Ukraine on these topics tend be less extreme.
Similar historical cleavages also remain evident at the level of individual social identification. Attitudes toward the most important political issue, relations with <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, differed strongly between <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a>, identifying more with <a href="Ukrainian%20nationalism">Ukrainian nationalism</a> and the <a href="Ukrainian%20Greek%20Catholic%20Church">Ukrainian Greek Catholic Church</a>, and <a href="Donetsk">Donetsk</a>, predominantly Russian orientated and favourable to the <a href="Soviet%20era">Soviet era</a>, while in central and southern Ukraine, as well as <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>, such divisions were less important and there was less antipathy toward people from other regions (a poll by the <a href="Research%20%26amp%3B%20Branding%20Group">Research & Branding Group</a> held March 2010 showed that the attitude of the citizens of Donetsk to the citizens of Lviv was 79% positive and that the attitude of the citizens of Lviv to the citizens of Donetsk was 88% positive).
However, all were united by an overarching Ukrainian identity based on shared economic difficulties, showing that other attitudes are determined more by culture and politics than by demographic differences. Surveys of regional identities in Ukraine have shown that the feeling of belonging to a "Soviet identity" is strongest in the <a href="Donbas">Donbas</a> (about 40%) and the Crimea (about 30%).
During <a href="Elections%20in%20Ukraine">elections</a> voters of Western and Central Ukrainian <a href="Oblasts%20of%20Ukraine">oblasts</a> (provinces) vote mostly for parties (<a href="Our%20Ukraine%E2%80%93People%27s%20Self-Defense%20Bloc">Our Ukraine</a>, <a href="All-Ukrainian%20Union%20%26quot%3BFatherland%26quot%3B">Batkivshchyna</a>) and presidential candidates (<a href="Viktor%20Yuschenko">Viktor Yuschenko</a>, <a href="Yulia%20Tymoshenko">Yulia Tymoshenko</a>) with a <a href="pro-Western">pro-Western</a> and state reform <a href="Political%20platform">platform</a>, while voters in Southern and Eastern oblasts vote for parties (<a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Ukraine">CPU</a>, <a href="Party%20of%20Regions">Party of Regions</a>) and presidential candidates (<a href="Viktor%20Yanukovych">Viktor Yanukovych</a>) with a <a href="pro-Russian">pro-Russian</a> and <a href="status%20quo">status quo</a> platform. However, this geographical division is decreasing.
Urbanisation.
In total, Ukraine has 457 cities, 176 of them are labelled oblast-class, 279 smaller -class cities, and two special legal status cities. These are followed by 886 urban-type settlements and 28,552 villages.
Culture.
Ukrainian customs are heavily influenced by <a href="Orthodox%20Christianity">Orthodox Christianity</a>, the dominant religion in the country. Gender roles also tend to be more traditional, and grandparents play a greater role in bringing up children, than in the West. The culture of Ukraine has also been influenced by its eastern and western neighbours, reflected in its <a href="Ukrainian%20architecture">architecture</a>, music and art.
The Communist era had quite a strong effect on the art and writing of Ukraine. In 1932, Stalin made <a href="socialist%20realism">socialist realism</a> state policy in the Soviet Union when he promulgated the decree "On the Reconstruction of Literary and Art Organisations". This greatly stifled creativity. During the 1980s <a href="glasnost">glasnost</a> (openness) was introduced and Soviet artists and writers again became free to express themselves as they wanted.
The tradition of the <a href="Easter%20egg">Easter egg</a>, known as <a href="pysanky">pysanky</a>, has long roots in Ukraine. These eggs were drawn on with wax to create a pattern; then, the dye was applied to give the eggs their pleasant colours, the dye did not affect the previously wax-coated parts of the egg. After the entire egg was dyed, the wax was removed leaving only the colourful pattern. This tradition is thousands of years old, and precedes the arrival of Christianity to Ukraine. In the city of <a href="Kolomyia">Kolomyia</a> near the foothills of the <a href="Carpathian%20Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> in 2000 was built the museum of Pysanka which won a nomination as the monument of modern Ukraine in 2007, part of the <a href="Seven%20Wonders%20of%20Ukraine">Seven Wonders of Ukraine</a> action.
Weaving and embroidery.
Artisan <a href="textile%20arts">textile arts</a> play an important role in Ukrainian culture, especially in <a href="Ukrainian%20wedding%20traditions">Ukrainian wedding traditions</a>. <a href="Ukrainian%20embroidery">Ukrainian embroidery</a>, <a href="weaving">weaving</a> and lace-making are used in traditional <a href="folk%20dress">folk dress</a> and in traditional celebrations. Ukrainian embroidery varies depending on the region of origin and the designs have a long history of motifs, compositions, choice of colours and types of stitches. Use of colour is very important and has roots in <a href="Ukrainian%20folklore">Ukrainian folklore</a>. Embroidery motifs found in different parts of Ukraine are preserved in the <a href="Rushnyk">Rushnyk</a> Museum in <a href="Pereiaslav">Pereiaslav</a>.
National dress is woven and highly decorated. Weaving with handmade looms is still practised in the village of Krupove, situated in <a href="Rivne%20Oblast">Rivne Oblast</a>. The village is the birthplace of two famous personalities in the scene of national crafts fabrication. Nina Myhailivna and Uliana Petrivna with international recognition. To preserve this traditional knowledge the village is planning to open a local weaving centre, a museum and weaving school.
Literature.
The history of Ukrainian literature dates back to the 11th century, following the Christianisation of Kievan Rus'. The writings of the time were mainly liturgical and were written in <a href="Old%20Church%20Slavonic">Old Church Slavonic</a>. Historical accounts of the time were referred to as "<a href="chronicle">chronicle</a>s", the most significant of which was the <a href="Primary%20Chronicle">Primary Chronicle</a>. Literary activity faced a sudden decline during the <a href="Mongol%20invasion%20of%20Rus%27">Mongol invasion of Rus'</a>.
Ukrainian literature again began to develop in the 14th century, and was advanced significantly in the 16th century with the introduction of <a href="printing">print</a> and with the beginning of the Cossack era, under both Russian and Polish dominance. The Cossacks established an independent society and popularized a <a href="Duma%20%28epic%29">new kind</a> of <a href="epic%20poem">epic poem</a>s, which marked a high point of Ukrainian <a href="oral%20literature">oral literature</a>. These advances were then set back in the 17th and early 18th centuries, when publishing in the Ukrainian language was outlawed and prohibited. Nonetheless, by the late 18th century modern literary Ukrainian finally emerged.
The 19th century initiated a <a href="vernacular">vernacular</a> period in Ukraine, led by <a href="Ivan%20Kotliarevsky">Ivan Kotliarevsky</a>'s work , the first publication written in modern Ukrainian. By the 1830s, Ukrainian <a href="romanticism">romanticism</a> began to develop, and the nation's most renowned cultural figure, romanticist poet-painter <a href="Taras%20Shevchenko">Taras Shevchenko</a> emerged. Where Ivan Kotliarevsky is considered to be the father of literature in the Ukrainian vernacular; Shevchenko is the father of a national revival.
Then, in 1863, use of the Ukrainian language in print was effectively <a href="Ems%20Ukaz">prohibited</a> by the Russian Empire. This severely curtailed literary activity in the area, and Ukrainian writers were forced to either publish their works in Russian or release them in Austrian controlled <a href="Galicia%20%28Central%20Europe%29">Galicia</a>. The ban was never officially lifted, but it became obsolete after the revolution and the Bolsheviks' coming to power.
Ukrainian literature continued to flourish in the early Soviet years, when nearly all literary trends were approved (the most important literary figures of that time were <a href="Mykola%20Khvylovy">Mykola Khvylovy</a>, <a href="Valerian%20Pidmohylny">Valerian Pidmohylny</a>, <a href="Mykola%20Kulish">Mykola Kulish</a>, <a href="Mykhayl%20Semenko">Mykhayl Semenko</a> and some others). These policies faced a steep decline in the 1930s, when prominent representatives as well as many others were killed by <a href="NKVD">NKVD</a> as part of the <a href="Great%20Purge">Great Purge</a>. In general around 223 writers were repressed by what was known as the <a href="Executed%20Renaissance">Executed Renaissance</a>. These repressions were part of Stalin's implemented policy of <a href="socialist%20realism">socialist realism</a>. The doctrine did not necessarily repress the use of the Ukrainian language, but it required that writers follow a certain style in their works.
In post-Stalinist times literary activities continued to be somewhat limited under the Communist Party. The most famous figures of Ukrainian post-war Soviet literature were <a href="Lina%20Kostenko">Lina Kostenko</a>, <a href="Dmytro%20Pavlychko">Dmytro Pavlychko</a>, <a href="Borys%20Oliynyk%20%28poet%29">Borys Oliynyk (poet)</a>, <a href="Ivan%20Drach">Ivan Drach</a>, <a href="Oles%20Honchar">Oles Honchar</a>, <a href="Vasyl%20Stus">Vasyl Stus</a>, <a href="Vasyl%20Symonenko">Vasyl Symonenko</a>.
Literary freedom grew in the late 1980s and early 1990s alongside the decline and collapse of the USSR and the reestablishment of Ukrainian independence in 1991.
Architecture.
Ukrainian architecture includes the motifs and styles that are found in structures built in modern Ukraine, and by <a href="Ukrainians">Ukrainians</a> worldwide.
These include initial roots which were established in the <a href="Eastern%20Slavs">Eastern Slavic</a> state of <a href="Kievan%20Rus%27">Kievan Rus'</a>. Since the <a href="Christianization%20of%20Kievan%20Rus%27">Christianization of Kievan Rus'</a> for several ages Ukrainian architecture was influenced by the <a href="Byzantine%20architecture">Byzantine architecture</a>. After the <a href="Mongol%20invasion%20of%20Rus">12th century</a>, the distinct <a href="architectural%20history">architectural history</a> continued in the principalities of <a href="Galicia-Volhynia">Galicia-Volhynia</a>. 
During the epoch of the <a href="Zaporozhian%20Cossacks">Zaporozhian Cossacks</a>, a new style unique to Ukraine was developed under the western influences of the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Lithuanian%20Commonwealth">Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth</a>. After the union with the <a href="Tsardom%20of%20Russia">Tsardom of Russia</a>, many structures in the larger eastern, Russian-ruled area were built in the styles of <a href="Russian%20architecture">Russian architecture</a> of that period, whilst the western <a href="Galicia%20%28Central%20Europe%29">Galicia</a> was developed under <a href="Architecture%20of%20Austria">Austro-Hungarian architectural influences</a>. Ukrainian national motifs would finally be used during the period of the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and in modern independent Ukraine.
The great <a href="Architecture%20of%20Kievan%20Rus%27">churches of the Rus'</a>, built after the <a href="Baptism%20of%20Kievan%20Rus%27">adoption of Christianity</a> in 988, were the first examples of monumental architecture in the East Slavic lands. The architectural style of the Kyivan state was strongly influenced by the <a href="Byzantine%20architecture">Byzantine</a>. Early <a href="Eastern%20Orthodox">Eastern Orthodox</a> churches were mainly made of wood, with the simplest form of church becoming known as a <a href="cell%20church">cell church</a>. Major cathedrals often featured scores of small domes, which led some art historians to take this as an indication of the appearance of pre-Christian pagan Slavic temples.
Several examples of these churches survive; however, during the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries, many were externally rebuilt in the <a href="Ukrainian%20Baroque">Ukrainian Baroque</a> style (see below). Examples include the grand <a href="Saint%20Sophia%27s%20Cathedral%2C%20Kyiv">St. Sophia of Kyiv</a>—the year 1017 is the earliest record of foundation laid, <a href="Church%20of%20the%20Saviour%20at%20Berestove">Church of the Saviour at Berestove</a>—built from 1113 to 1125 and <a href="St.%20Cyril%27s%20Monastery%2C%20Kyiv">St. Cyril's Church</a>, circa 12th-century. All can still be found in the Ukrainian capital. 
Several buildings were reconstructed during the late-19th century, including the in <a href="Volodymyr-Volynskyi">Volodymyr-Volynskyi</a>, built in 1160 and reconstructed in 1896–1900, the , built in 1201 with reconstruction done in the late 1940s, and the <a href="Golden%20Gate%2C%20Kyiv">Golden gates in Kyiv</a>, built in 1037 and reconstructed in 1982. The latter's reconstruction was criticised by some art and architecture historians as a revivalist fantasy. Unfortunately little secular or <a href="vernacular%20architecture">vernacular architecture</a> of Kievan Rus' has survived.
As Ukraine became increasingly integrated into the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a>, Russian architects had the opportunity to realise their projects in the picturesque landscape that many Ukrainian cities and regions offered. <a href="St%20Andrew%27s%20Church%2C%20Kyiv">St. Andrew's Church of Kyiv</a> (1747–1754), built by <a href="Bartolomeo%20Rastrelli">Bartolomeo Rastrelli</a>, is a notable example of <a href="Baroque">Baroque</a> architecture, and its location on top of the Kyivan mountain made it a recognisable monument of the city. An equally notable contribution of Rasetrelli was the <a href="Mariinskyi%20Palace">Mariinskyi Palace</a>, which was built to be a summer residence to Russian Empress <a href="Elizabeth%20of%20Russia">Elizabeth</a>. 
During the reign of the last <a href="Hetmans%20of%20Ukrainian%20Cossacks">Hetman of Ukraine</a>, <a href="Kirill%20Razumovsky">Kirill Razumovsky</a>, many of the <a href="Cossack%20Hetmanate">Cossack Hetmanate</a>'s towns such as <a href="Hlukhiv">Hlukhiv</a>, <a href="Baturyn">Baturyn</a> and <a href="Koselets">Koselets</a> had grandiose projects built by <a href="Andrey%20Kvasov">Andrey Kvasov</a>. Russia eventually conquered the south of Ukraine and Crimea, and renamed them as <a href="New%20Russia">New Russia</a>. New cities such as <a href="Mykolayiv">Nikolayev</a>, <a href="Odessa">Odessa</a>, <a href="Kherson">Kherson</a> and <a href="Sevastopol">Sevastopol</a> were founded. These would contain notable examples of Imperial Russian architecture.
In 1934, the capital of Soviet Ukraine moved from <a href="Kharkiv">Kharkiv</a> to <a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a>. Previously, the city was seen as only a regional centre, hence received little attention. All of that was to change, at great price. The first examples of <a href="Stalinist%20architecture">Stalinist architecture</a> were already showing, and, in light of the official policy, a new city was to be built on top of the old one. This meant that much-admired examples such as the <a href="St.%20Michael%27s%20Golden-Domed%20Monastery">St. Michael's Golden-Domed Monastery</a> were destroyed. 
Even the St. Sophia Cathedral was under threat. Also, the Second World War contributed to the wreckage. After the war, a new project for the reconstruction of central Kyiv transformed <a href="Khreshchatyk">Khreshchatyk</a> avenue into a notable example of Stalinism in Architecture. However, by 1955, the new politics of architecture once again stopped the project from fully being realised.
The task for modern Ukrainian architecture is diverse application of modern aesthetics, the search for an architect's own artistic style and inclusion of the existing historico-cultural environment. An example of modern Ukrainian architecture is the reconstruction and renewal of the <a href="Maidan%20Nezalezhnosti">Maidan Nezalezhnosti</a> in central Kyiv. Despite the limit set by narrow space within the plaza, the engineers were able to blend together the uneven landscape, and use underground space for a new shopping centre.
A major project, which may take up most of the 21st century, is the construction of the Kyiv City-Centre on the <a href="Rybalskyi%20Peninsula">Rybalskyi Peninsula</a>, which, when finished, will include a dense skyscraper park amid the picturesque landscape of the <a href="Dnieper%20River">Dnieper</a>.
Music.
Music is a major part of Ukrainian culture, with a long history and many influences. From traditional <a href="folk%20music">folk music</a>, to <a href="classical%20music">classical</a> and <a href="modern%20rock">modern rock</a>, Ukraine has produced several internationally recognised musicians including <a href="Kirill%20Karabits">Kirill Karabits</a>, <a href="Okean%20Elzy">Okean Elzy</a> and <a href="Ruslana">Ruslana</a>. Elements from traditional Ukrainian folk music made their way into Western music and even into modern <a href="jazz">jazz</a>.
Ukrainian music sometimes presents a perplexing mix of exotic melismatic singing with chordal harmony. The most striking general characteristic of authentic ethnic Ukrainian folk music is the wide use of minor modes or keys which incorporate augmented 2nd intervals.
During the Baroque period, music was an important discipline for those that had received a higher education in Ukraine. It had a place of considerable importance in the curriculum of the <a href="Kyiv-Mohyla%20Academy">Kyiv-Mohyla Academy</a>. Much of the nobility was well versed in music with many Ukrainian Cossack leaders such as (Mazepa, Paliy, Holovatyj, Sirko) being accomplished players of the <a href="kobza">kobza</a>, <a href="bandura">bandura</a> or <a href="torban">torban</a>.
The first dedicated musical academy was set up in Hlukhiv, Ukraine in 1738 and students were taught to sing, play violin and bandura from manuscripts. As a result, many of the earliest composers and performers within the Russian empire were ethnically Ukrainian, having been born or educated in Hlukhiv, or had been closely associated with this music school.
See: <a href="Dmytro%20Bortniansky">Dmytro Bortniansky</a>, <a href="Maksym%20Berezovsky">Maksym Berezovsky</a> and <a href="Artemy%20Vedel">Artemiy Vedel</a>.
Ukrainian classical music falls into three distinct categories defined by whether the composer was of Ukrainian ethnicity living in Ukraine, a composer of non-Ukrainian ethnicity who was born or at some time was a citizen of Ukraine, or an ethnic Ukrainian living outside of Ukraine within the <a href="Ukrainian%20diaspora">Ukrainian diaspora</a>. The music of these three groups differs considerably, as do the audiences for whom they cater.
Since the mid-1960s, Western-influenced pop music has been growing in popularity in Ukraine. Folk singer and harmonium player <a href="Mariana%20Sadovska">Mariana Sadovska</a> is prominent. Ukrainian pop and folk music arose with the international popularity of groups and performers like <a href="Vopli%20Vidoplyasova">Vopli Vidoplyasova</a>, <a href="Dakh%20Daughters">Dakh Daughters</a>, <a href="Dakha%20Brakha">Dakha Brakha</a>, <a href="Ivan%20Dorn">Ivan Dorn</a> and <a href="Okean%20Elzy">Okean Elzy</a>.
Modern musical culture of Ukraine is presented both with academic and entertainment music. Ukraine has five conservatories, 6 opera houses, five houses of Chamber Music, Philharmony in all regional centers.
Ukraine hosted the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202005">Eurovision Song Contest 2005</a> and the <a href="Eurovision%20Song%20Contest%202017">Eurovision Song Contest 2017</a>.
Cinema.
Ukraine has had an influence on the history of the cinema. Ukrainian directors <a href="Alexander%20Dovzhenko">Alexander Dovzhenko</a>, often cited as one of the most important early Soviet filmmakers, as well as being a pioneer of <a href="Soviet%20montage%20theory">Soviet montage theory</a>, <a href="Dovzhenko%20Film%20Studios">Dovzhenko Film Studios</a>, and <a href="Sergei%20Parajanov">Sergei Parajanov</a>, Armenian film director and artist who made significant contributions to Ukrainian, Armenian and Georgian cinema. He invented his own cinematic style, Ukrainian poetic cinema, which was totally out of step with the guiding principles of socialist realism.
Other important directors including <a href="Kira%20Muratova">Kira Muratova</a>, <a href="Sergei%20Loznitsa">Sergei Loznitsa</a>, <a href="Myroslav%20Slaboshpytskyi">Myroslav Slaboshpytskyi</a>, <a href="Larisa%20Shepitko">Larisa Shepitko</a>, <a href="Sergei%20Bondarchuk">Sergei Bondarchuk</a>, <a href="Leonid%20Bykov">Leonid Bykov</a>, <a href="Yuri%20Ilyenko">Yuri Ilyenko</a>, <a href="Leonid%20Osyka">Leonid Osyka</a>, <a href="Ihor%20Podolchak">Ihor Podolchak</a> with his <a href="Delirium%20%282013%20film%29">Delirium</a> and <a href="Maryna%20Vroda">Maryna Vroda</a>. Many Ukrainian actors have achieved international fame and critical success, including: <a href="Vera%20Kholodnaya">Vera Kholodnaya</a>, <a href="Bohdan%20Stupka">Bohdan Stupka</a>, <a href="Milla%20Jovovich">Milla Jovovich</a>, <a href="Olga%20Kurylenko">Olga Kurylenko</a>, <a href="Mila%20Kunis">Mila Kunis</a>.
Despite a history of important and successful productions, the industry has often been characterised by a debate about its identity and the level of European and Russian influence. Ukrainian producers are active in international co-productions and Ukrainian actors, directors and crew feature regularly in Russian (Soviet in past) films. Also successful films have been based on Ukrainian people, stories or events, including <a href="Battleship%20Potemkin">Battleship Potemkin</a>, <a href="Man%20with%20a%20Movie%20Camera">Man with a Movie Camera</a>, , <a href="Everything%20Is%20Illuminated%20%28film%29">Everything Is Illuminated</a>.
Ukrainian State Film Agency owns <a href="National%20Oleksandr%20Dovzhenko%20Film%20Centre">National Oleksandr Dovzhenko Film Centre</a>, film copying laboratory and archive, takes part in hosting of the <a href="Odessa%20International%20Film%20Festival">Odessa International Film Festival</a>, and <a href="Molodist">Molodist</a> is the only one <a href="FIAPF">FIAPF</a> accredited International Film Festival held in Ukraine; competition program is devoted to student, first short and first full feature films from all over the world. Held annually in October.
Media.
<a href="Ukrayinska%20Pravda">Ukrayinska Pravda</a> was founded by <a href="Georgiy%20Gongadze">Georgiy Gongadze</a> in April 2000 (the day of the Ukrainian constitutional referendum). Published mainly in Ukrainian with selected articles published in or translated to Russian and English, the newspaper has particular emphasis on the politics of Ukraine. Freedom of the press in Ukraine is considered to be among the freest of the post-Soviet states other than the Baltic states.
<a href="Freedom%20House">Freedom House</a> classifies the Internet in Ukraine as "free" and the press as "partly free". Press freedom has significantly improved since the Orange Revolution of 2004. However, in 2010 Freedom House perceived "negative trends in Ukraine".
<a href="Kyiv">Kyiv</a> dominates the media sector in Ukraine: the "<a href="Kyiv%20Post">Kyiv Post</a>" is Ukraine's leading English-language newspaper. National <a href="List%20of%20newspapers%20in%20Ukraine">newspapers</a> "<a href="Den%20%28newspaper%29">Den</a>", "<a href="Dzerkalo%20Tyzhnia">Dzerkalo Tyzhnia</a>", tabloids, such as "<a href="The%20Ukrainian%20Week">The Ukrainian Week</a>" or "<a href="Focus%20%28Ukrainian%20magazine%29">Focus</a>", and television and radio are largely based there, although <a href="Lviv">Lviv</a> is also a significant national media centre. The National News Agency of Ukraine, <a href="Ukrinform">Ukrinform</a> was founded here in 1918. The Ukrainian publishing sector, including books, directories and databases, journals, magazines and business media, newspapers and news agencies, has a combined turnover. <a href="Sanoma">Sanoma</a> publishes Ukrainian editions of such magazines as "<a href="Esquire%20%28magazine%29">Esquire</a>", "<a href="Harpers%20Bazaar">Harpers Bazaar</a>" and "<a href="National%20Geographic%20Magazine">National Geographic Magazine</a>". <a href="BBC%20Ukrainian">BBC Ukrainian</a> started its broadcasts in 1992.
Ukrainians listen to radio programming, such as <a href="Radio%20Ukraine">Radio Ukraine</a> or <a href="Radio%20Liberty">Radio Liberty</a>, largely commercial, on average just over two-and-a-half hours a day. Several television channels operate, and many websites are popular.
Sport.
Ukraine greatly benefited from the Soviet emphasis on <a href="physical%20education">physical education</a>. Such policies left Ukraine with hundreds of stadia, swimming pools, gymnasia and many other athletic facilities. The most popular sport is <a href="Association%20football">football</a>. The top professional league is the <a href="Ukrainian%20Premier%20League">Vyscha Liha</a> ("premier league").
Many Ukrainians also played for the <a href="Soviet%20national%20football%20team">Soviet national football team</a>, most notably <a href="Ballon%20d%27Or">Ballon d'Or</a> winners <a href="Ihor%20Belanov">Ihor Belanov</a> and <a href="Oleh%20Blokhin">Oleh Blokhin</a>. This award was only presented to one Ukrainian after the dissolution of the Soviet Union, <a href="Andriy%20Shevchenko">Andriy Shevchenko</a>. The national team made its debut in the <a href="2006%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">2006 FIFA World Cup</a>, and reached the quarterfinals before losing to eventual champions, <a href="Italy%20national%20football%20team">Italy</a>.
Ukrainian <a href="boxing">boxers</a> are amongst the best in the world. The brothers <a href="Vitali%20Klitschko">Vitali</a> and <a href="Wladimir%20Klitschko">Wladimir Klitschko</a> are former <a href="heavyweight">heavyweight</a> world champions who held multiple world titles throughout their careers. Also hailing from Ukraine, <a href="Vasyl%20Lomachenko">Vasyl Lomachenko</a>, a <a href="2008%20Summer%20Olympics">2008</a> and <a href="2012%20Olympic%20games">2012 Olympic</a> gold medalist. He is the <a href="Unified%20champion">unified</a> <a href="lightweight">lightweight</a> world champion who ties the record for winning a world title in the fewest professional fights; three. As of September 2018, he is ranked as the world's best active boxer, <a href="pound%20for%20pound">pound for pound</a>, by <a href="boxing%20pound%20for%20pound%20rankings%23ESPN">ESPN</a>,
<a href="Sergey%20Bubka">Sergey Bubka</a> held the record in the <a href="Pole%20vault">Pole vault</a> from 1993 to 2014; with great strength, speed and gymnastic abilities, he was voted the world's best athlete on several occasions.
<a href="Basketball">Basketball</a> is becoming popular in Ukraine. In 2011, Ukraine was granted a right to organize <a href="EuroBasket%202015">EuroBasket 2015</a>. Two years later the <a href="Ukraine%20national%20basketball%20team">Ukraine national basketball team</a> finished 6th in <a href="EuroBasket%202013">EuroBasket 2013</a> and qualified to <a href="2014%20FIBA%20Basketball%20World%20Cup">FIBA World Cup</a> for the first time in its history. <a href="Euroleague">Euroleague</a> participant <a href="BC%20Budivelnyk">Budivelnyk Kyiv</a> is the strongest professional basketball club in Ukraine.
<a href="Chess">Chess</a> is a popular sport in Ukraine. <a href="Ruslan%20Ponomariov">Ruslan Ponomariov</a> is the former world champion. There are about 85 <a href="Grandmaster%20%28chess%29">Grandmasters</a> and 198 <a href="International%20Masters">International Masters</a> in Ukraine.
<a href="Rugby%20league">Rugby league</a> is played throughout Ukraine.
Ukraine made its Olympic debut at the <a href="1994%20Winter%20Olympics">1994 Winter Olympics</a>. So far, <a href="Ukraine%20at%20the%20Olympics">Ukraine at the Olympics</a> has been much more successful in <a href="Summer%20Olympics">Summer Olympics</a> (115 medals in five appearances) than in the <a href="Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>. Ukraine is ranked 35th by number of gold medals won in the <a href="All-time%20Olympic%20Games%20medal%20count">All-time Olympic Games medal count</a>, with every country above it, except for Russia, having more appearances.
Cuisine.
The traditional Ukrainian diet includes chicken, pork, beef, fish and mushrooms. Ukrainians also tend to eat a lot of potatoes, grains, fresh, boiled or pickled vegetables. Popular traditional dishes include (boiled dumplings with mushrooms, potatoes, sauerkraut, cottage cheese, cherries or berries), <a href="nalysnyky">nalysnyky</a> (pancakes with cottage cheese, poppy seeds, mushrooms, caviar or meat), <a href="kapu%C5%9Bniak">kapuśniak</a> (soup made with meat, potatoes, carrots, onions, cabbage, millet, tomato paste, spices and fresh herbs), <a href="borscht">borscht</a> (soup made of beets, cabbage and mushrooms or meat), (stuffed cabbage rolls filled with rice, carrots, onion and minced meat) and <a href="pierogi">pierogi</a> (dumplings filled with boiled potatoes and cheese or meat). Ukrainian specialties also include <a href="Chicken%20Kiev">Chicken Kiev</a> and <a href="Kyiv%20cake">Kyiv cake</a>. Ukrainians drink <a href="kompot">stewed fruit</a>, juices, milk, buttermilk (they make cottage cheese from this), mineral water, tea and coffee, beer, wine and .
